resources.title: Reform: The Church at the Birth of Protestantism
resources.author: Luke H. Davis
resources.rationale: This book continues from the previous one in the series that is read in Term 1. Now the events and people of the Reformation are discussed during a time when the church had drifted from the Scriptures. Students will read about Martin Luther, Thomas Cranmer, Lady Jane Grey, and others who risked their lives to stand up for what they believed.

resources.title: Regional Field Guides for Wildflowers, Birds, Trees, Animals, etc.
resources.author: Various
resources.maySub: any field guides for your area. Look for guides with drawings rather than photographs.

resources.title: Reign: The Church in the Middle Ages
resources.author: Luke H. Davis
resources.rationale: This book is a narrative-driven history of the Church written for young people. Introducing key people and events from the Middle Ages, students will read about the lives of Benedict, Francis of Assisi, Julian of Norwich, and John Hus.

resources.title: Remaking the World: How 1776 Created the Post-Christian West
Rembrandt Is in the Wind: Learning to Love Art through the Eyes of Faith
resources.author: Russ Ramsey
resources.rationale: Part art history, part biblical study, part philosophy, and part analysis of the human experience, this book is nonetheless all story. From Michelangelo to Vincent van Gogh to Edward Hopper, the lives of the artists in this book illustrate the struggle of living in this world and point to the beauty of the redemption available to us in Christ. Each story is different. Some conclude with resounding triumph while others end in struggle. But all of them raise important questions about humanity's hunger and capacity for glory, and all of them teach us to love and see beauty.

resources.title: Remembering John McCrae
resources.author: Linda Granfield
resources.rationale: Explore Canada in the early 20th century as we follow doctor and poet John McCrae from his childhood home in Guelph to the battlefields of WWI. This engaging biography introduces students to Canada at the turn of the century and Canada’s contributions to WWI.

resources.title: Renewal: The Church That Expands Outward
resources.author: Luke H. Davis
resources.rationale: The nearly three centuries covered in this volume give us a picture of the incredible energy and great expansion of the Church throughout the world following the Protestant Reformation, and the people who led the way through a variety of abilities that God gave them.
resources.note: Use option one link to receive discount.

resources.title: Revolutionary Soldier: 1775-1783
resources.author: C. Keith Wilbur
resources.rationale: Great line drawings for Book of Centuries entries.

resources.title: Richard III
resources.author: William Shakespeare
resources.rationale: Shakespeare's play, sometimes labeled a history and sometimes a tragedy, is about a famous figure in English history from the late 1400s. This play will be especially poignant for students in Grades 9-12 who are reading Daughter of Time in their other literature lessons.

resources.title: Richard III (Audio recording)
resources.author: Arkangel
resources.maySub: Librivox recording
resources.rationale: This arkangel recording brings Richard III to life and eases students into the flow of Shakespeare's prose.

resources.title: Rip Van Winkle & The Legend of Sleepy Hollow
resources.author: Washington Irving
resources.maySub: any unabridged version of Rip Van Winkle (the Legend of Sleepy Hollow is not assigned in the lesson plans).
resources.rationale: Rip Van Winkle lives in Colonial New York. One day, he falls asleep - and stays asleep for 20 years. When he finally wakes, he literally finds himself in a different country, because he has missed the entire American Revolution! A classic tale from an American author born just before the turn of the 19th century.

resources.title: Robert Boyle: Trailblazer of Science
resources.author: John Tiner
resources.rationale: Robert Boyle was one of the most prolific figures in the Scientific Revolution and the leading scientist of his day. He was born in Ireland in 1627 to one of the wealthiest families in Britain. This book sets the life of Boyle in the context of the tumultuous events of the 17th century, including the Irish Rebellion, the execution of Charles I, and the Great Fire of London. Students will learn about a scientist who believed that science and faith were not mutually exclusive, but that the study of the world illuminated the glory of God.

resources.author: Daniel DeFoe

resources.rationale: This year's study explores the diverse origins of American democracy, from the Normandy invasion of England in 1066 A.D. to the representative forms of government developed by American Indian tribes before European contact.

resources.title: Roots, Shoots, Buckets, & Boots: Activities to Do in the Garden
resources.author: Sharon Lovejoy

resources.title: Rubicon

resources.note: Sensitive Content. Optional read for interested students. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Runner in the Sun

resources.title: Sailing Alone Around the World

resources.title: Saint Thomas Aquinas: A Biography for Young Readers
resources.author: Mary Ellen Evans, Margaret Nichols, & Geoffrey Gneuhs
resources.rationale: This biography of St Thomas Aquinas covers the highlights of Thomas’s life, from a young son of a wealthy Italian family to a Dominican friar and an influential philosopher and theologian. His writings have had an impact on the Catholic church that remains to this day. This is a great introduction to this Dominican saint and is very readable for students.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read.

resources.title: Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat: Mastering the Elements of Good Cooking
resources.author: Samin Nosrat
resources.rationale: Whether for afternoon occupations or High School Food Science, young cooks will be inspired by this well-written text with its engaging narrative and beautiful illustrations.  The author does a good job of introducing the basic ingredients of cooking without requiring a full chemistry course; students who have already taken chemistry will find additional connections to enhance their understanding even more.

resources.title: Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat: Mastering the Elements of Good Cooking
resources.author: Samin Nosrat
resources.rationale: ransform how you prep, cook, and think about food with this visionary masterclass in cooking by Samin Nosrat that distills decades of professional experience into just four simple elements.

resources.title: Sarah Bishop
resources.author: Scott O'Dell
resources.rationale: Left alone after the deaths of her father and brother, who had taken opposite sides in the War of Independence, Sarah Bishop flees from the British who seek to arrest her and struggles to shape a new life for herself in the wilderness.

resources.title: Seen and Unseen: What Dorothea Lange, Toyo Miyatake, and Ansel Adams's Photographs Reveal About the Japanese American Incarceration
resources.author: Elizabeth Partridge
resources.rationale: Graphic novel showing the experience and perspective of three photographers who documented the Japanese American incarceration.

resources.title: Seesaw Girl
resources.author: Linda Sue Park
resources.rationale: Set in 17th-century Korea, this story introduces us to Jade Blossom, a young girl who spends all of her days inside her family's home grounds, as is the custom for all women and girls from wealthy families. Jade Blossom longs to see the outside world, and this propels her into mishaps and adventures, which gives students much to ponder about the nature of contentment, societal structures, foreign policy in 17th-century Korea, and more.
resources.note: Students should choose this OR Arrow Over the Door.

resources.title: Selected Stories of H. G. Wells
resources.author: H.G. Wells

resources.title: Sense & Sensibility
resources.author: Jane Austen
resources.maySub: another edition, Pride and Prejudice from Grades 9-10, or another Austen novel
resources.rationale: Centering around the two Dashwood sisters, this popular novel by Jane Austen contrasts the ideals of "Sense" and "Sensibility" which rivaled each other in her culture and continue to clash in ours today.
resources.note: We recommend this beautiful edition annotated by Karen Swallow Prior because of it's helpful introduction, annotations, and thoughtful discussion questions from a Christian perspective.

resources.title: Sentence Island
resources.author: Michael Clay Thompson
resources.rationale: This program brings story, delight, and ideas to the study of grammar. In this book, students focus on the science and art of forming a good sentence and learn the rules and concepts that are essential for formal writing.

resources.title: Seven Daughters and Seven Sons
resources.author: Barbara Cohen, Bahija Lovejoy
resources.rationale: Based on an Iraqi folk tale, this beautiful story takes students into the tents and caravans of merchants from Damascus to Baghdad, Tyre, and Sidon.  Told from the perspective of several different characters, the book is also a poignant story about friendship, personhood, and love.
resources.note: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

resources.title: Seven Days that Divide the World
resources.author: John C. Lennox
resources.rationale:
What did the writer of Genesis mean by "the first day?" Are the seven days in Genesis 1 a literal week or a series of time periods? If I believe that the earth is 4.5 billion years old as cosmologists believe, am I denying the authority of Scripture?
With examples from history, a brief but thorough exploration of the major interpretations, and a look into the particular significance of the creation of human beings, Lennox suggests that Christians can heed modern scientific knowledge while staying faithful to the biblical narrative. He moves beyond a simple response to the controversy, insisting that Genesis teaches us far more about the God of Jesus Christ and about God's intention for creation than it does about the age of the earth.
With this book, Lennox offers a careful and accessible introduction to a scientifically-savvy, theologically-astute, and Scripturally faithful interpretation of Genesis.

resources.title: Sewing School
resources.author: Andria Lisle and Amie Petronis Plumley
resources.rationale: This book teaches basic stitches and techniques and includes lots of simple sewing projects for the beginner.

resources.title: Sewing School 2: Lessons in Machine Sewing; 20 Projects Kids Will Love to Make
resources.author: Andria Lisle and Amie Petronis Plumley

resources.title: Sewing School Quilts: 15 Projects Kids Will Love to Make; Stitch Up a Patchwork Pet, Scrappy Journal, T-Shirt Quilt, and More
resources.author: Amie Petronis Plumley and Andria Lisle

resources.title: Shadow and Light: A Journey into Advent
resources.author: Tsh Oxenreider
resources.rationale:
May sub Biola Advent & Lent Project.
A simple yet thoughtful guide to help reclaim the holiday season as a time to remember Jesus’ first coming; includes scripture readings and reflection time.

resources.title: Shadow Catcher: How Edward S. Curtis Documented American Indian Dignity and Beauty
resources.author: Michael Burgan
resources.rationale: Edward S. Curtis documents American Indian dignity and beauty.

resources.title: Shadows on the Rock
resources.author: Willa Cather
resources.rationale: Willa Cather's novel is set in the Quebec of 1697: a small, isolated settlement on a rock in the St. Lawrence River, surrounded by forest. It is a quiet novel peopled by those who found refuge in New France - fur traders, adventurers, merchants, mystics, nuns, and priests - and told through the eyes of twelve-year-old Cécile, who comes to realize she is more at home in Quebec than in the France her family left behind. This novel is an excellent supplement to the history spines, as the fictional characters occupy a historically accurate world, interacting with true historical figures and reacting to historical events. \*This book has some outdated descriptions of Indigenous Canadians.\*

resources.title: Shakespeare After All
resources.author: Marjorie Garber
resources.rationale: Teacher resource that goes into more depth about 38 of Shakespeare's plays.

resources.title: Shakespeare's Restless World
resources.author: Neil MacGregor
resources.rationale: At the beginning of Henry V, Shakespeare asked his audience to 'Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts': but what mental world did the Elizabethans draw on to fill out the 'vasty fields of France', Cleopatra's barge, or Julius Caesar's forum? In this book, Neil MacGregor attempts to revisit the world of Elizabethan experience through discussions of objects including a communion cup, a rapier, a peddler's trunk, and a holy relic - traveling 'through the charisma of things, to a past world'.

resources.title: Shanleya's Quest Card Game
resources.author: Thomas Elpel
resources.rationale: Botany in a Day author, Thomas Elpel, produced this deck of cards to help students begin to notice the patterns that are used to characterize common plant families.
resources.note:
For Grade 5, this resource is not required but is highly recommended for optional activities included in the lesson plans.
For the Botany Elective in HS, this resource is REQUIRED.

resources.title: Sing Down the Moon
resources.author: Scott O'Dell

resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Once you sign up, you'll have to randomly select a church, and then you can search in the song library for a hymn you'd like to learn, adjust the audio for the part you'd like to hear, and then begin singing! Because of copyright restrictions, only older hymns are generally available.

resources.author: Karen Johnson
resources.rationale: Singing Bird: Molly Ockett: A Maine Legend captures colonial New England at its most turbulent time. With authentic historical detail and richly drawn characters, the book charts the life of one remarkable Native American woman who endures through unimaginable circumstances and continues to live today in the imagination of New Englanders.
resources.note: Students may read this book OR The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing

He uses many quotes from people from Church history so students will be exposed to the thoughts of people such as Jonathan Edwards, Charles Spurgeon, and Francis Schaeffer. This is a book that they can grow into and hopefully keep on their shelf as a resource for many years to come.

resources.author: Ursula Le Guin

resources.title: Stewards of Eden: What Scripture Says About the Environment and Why It Matters
resources.author: Sandra L. Richter
resources.rationale: Richter is a master Bible scholar. Each chapter draws out a biblical mandate about humanity's responsibility to care for the land, domestic and wild creatures, and people on the margins.

resources.title: Stories from Chaucer Retold From The Canterbury Tales
resources.author: Joseph Walker McSpadden
resources.rationale: An age-appropriate enjoyable collection to introduce students to some of Chaucer's most famous tales.

resources.title: Stories from Shakespeare
resources.author: Marchette Chute
resources.rationale: A highly recommended "retelling" book that offers the plot, some quotes, and a bit of explanation. A perfect teacher resource to read before starting the play.

resources.title: Stories From the History of Rome
resources.author: Emily Beesly
resources.rationale: This is a narrative introduction to the stories students will read later in Plutarch's Lives.
resources.note: Contains some violence that may be disturbing for sensitive children.

resources.title: Stories in Stone from the Roman Forum
resources.author: Isabel Lovell

resources.title: Stories of America vol.2
resources.author: Charles Morris, Sonya Shafer
resources.rationale: This series, originally written in 1901 by Charles Morris, has been lightly edited and updated for today's readers.

resources.title: Stories of the Nations Vol.2
resources.author: Lorene Lambert
resources.rationale: This book picks up after the death of Lincoln.

resources.title: Stories To Solve: Folktales From Around The World
resources.author: George Shannon
resources.rationale: A beautifully illustrated book of short tales from around the world to draw students into puzzles of words and history. Each page has a short riddle and the next gives the solution.

resources.title: Stowaway
resources.author: Karen Hesse
resources.rationale: This is the story of Nicholas Young, a boy who snuck onto Captain Cook's ship as it was leaving on a three-year voyage to find an unknown continent at the bottom of the world.

resources.title: String, Straight-Edge, and Shadow
resources.author: Julia Diggins
resources.maySub: previous edition.
resources.rationale: Follows the development of geometry from the need to be able to engineer structures that would stand to the theoretical ideas of Pythagoras and Thales.

resources.title: Struggle For A Continent: The French and Indian Wars: 1689-1763
resources.author: Betsy Maestro
resources.rationale: _Struggle for a Continent_ recounts the riveting story of the French and British dynastic conflicts over dominion of North American between 1689-1763. It allows students to locate the major events of this historical period in Canada - such as the fighting over New France, the sieges on Louisbourg, the Acadian Expulsion, and the Battle of the Plains of Abraham - within the context of wider intercolonial fighting throughout the continent.

resources.title: Stuart Little
resources.author: E. B. White
resources.rationale: Stuart Little is no ordinary mouse. Born to a family of humans, he lives in New York City with his parents, his older brother George, and Snowbell the cat. Though he's shy and thoughtful, he's also a true lover of adventure. Stuart's greatest adventure comes when his best friend, a beautiful little bird named Margalo, disappears from her nest. Determined to track her down, Stuart ventures away from home for the very first time in his life. He finds adventure aplenty. But will he find his friend?

resources.title: Student World Atlas 6th Ed.
resources.author: National Geographic
resources.maySub: other atlases; however, map work and other lessons refer specifically to this one.
resources.rationale: This atlas is used across the curriculum as a reference and as a text to read in some lessons. With interesting information and pictures, this is an economical reference for students.

resources.title: Style: The Basics of Clarity & Grace 5th ed.
resources.author: Joseph Williams, Joseph Bizup
resources.maySub: Another edition, but some content will not match exactly.
resources.rationale: This classic work covers elemental principles of writing that will help students diagnose the strengths and weaknesses of their prose quickly and revise effectively. The text is written in a conversational style, offering reason-based principles for clear writing.
resources.note: The loose-leaf edition is the most affordable and allows students to put the book directly in a composition binder. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Sufferings in Africa: The Astonishing Account of a New England Sea Captain Enslaved by North African Arabs
resources.author: Captain James Riley
resources.rationale: A true tale of shipwreck that a young Abraham Lincoln read.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Sunjata: A New Prose Edition
resources.author: David Conrad
resources.rationale: "After existing orally for hundreds of years, _Sunjata_ was written down in the 20th century. David Conrad, who recorded a new version of the epic, has now crafted a prose translation that preserves the oral flavor of live performance. The result is a captivating work of literature that will finally give the story of _Sunjata_ its well-deserved place among the great epics of world literature."

resources.title: Sunjata: Warrior King of Mali
resources.author: Justine Fontes, Ron Fontes, Sandy Carruthers
resources.rationale: A young hero who overcame the unthinkable rises to unite his people. Weak and silent, young Sunjata is unable to walk, unable even to pull a bow. But a prophesy foretold that his mother would bear a son who will become the mansa of all the Mande people―the greatest king ever to rule. Sunjata rounds out Grade 7-8 students' study of mythology by introducing them to this ancient story from Western Africa through the authors' carefully researched storytelling and visuals. For Grades 11-12, this book serves as an introduction to orient students to the fuller narrative.
resources.note: Budget tip: This book will be read over only a few lessons, so is an ideal title to get from the library.

resources.title: Sunshine Makes the Seasons
resources.author: Dr. Franklyn M. Branley
resources.rationale: Note that there is an activity in this storybook that students can try if they want, but don't worry if it is conceptually challenging. They will revisit this activity in Form 3.

resources.title: Tales from Grimm
resources.author: Wanda Gag
resources.rationale: Mason had her youngest students read fairy tales from Grimm or Anderson. This retelling by Wanda Gag is gentler and less scary than many other translations, while still having good literary quality and simple English for students to practice reading themselves.

resources.title: Tales from Shakespeare
resources.author: Charles and Mary Lamb
resources.rationale: An introduction to the study of Shakespeare.

resources.title: Tales from the Hive Companion Website
resources.author: PBS Nova
resources.rationale: A website with lots of information and pictures to explore.

resources.title: Tales of a Korean Grandmother: 32 Traditional Tales from Korea
resources.author: Frances Carpenter

resources.title: Tales Our Abuelitas Told: A Hispanic Folktale Collection
resources.author: Alma Flor Ada & F. Isabel Campoy
resources.rationale: This is the English translation of the story collection that is used for literature lessons.

resources.title: Tales the Totems Tell
resources.author: Hugh Weatherby
resources.rationale: This excerpt contains the story of the first totem pole and the most common totem figure, the raven.
resources.note: PDF provided for member use only under Fair Use Copyright Law.

resources.title: Tanglewood Tales
resources.author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
resources.rationale: More stories from Cousin Eustace and the children.

resources.title: Tank Man: How a Photograph Defined China's Protest Movement
resources.author: Michael Burgan

resources.title: Tap Dancing on the Roof: Sijo (Poems)
resources.author: Linda Sue Park

resources.title: Tasting History
resources.author: Max Miller
resources.rationale: Including the original recipe and Miller’s modern recreation, this cookbook is a must-have for any avid cook or history fan looking to experience delicious recipes from the past.

resources.title: Tech-Wise Family: Everyday Steps for Putting Technology in its Proper Place
resources.author: Andy Crouch

resources.title: Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs: A Popular History of Ancient Egypt 2nd ed.
resources.author: Barbara Mertz
resources.rationale: A fascinating chronicle of an extraordinary people—from the first Stone Age settlements through the reign of Cleopatra and the Roman invasions—_Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs_ brings ancient Egypt to life as never before. Lavishly illustrated with pictures, maps, and photographs, it offers tantalizing glimpses into Egyptian society; amazing stories of the pharaohs and the rise and fall of great dynasties; a sampling of culture, religion, and folklore; stories of explorers, scientists, and scoundrels who sought to unravel or exploit the ageless mysteries; and new insights into the architectural wonders that were raised along the banks of the Nile.
resources.note: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

resources.title: Tennyson: Poems (Everyman's Library)
resources.author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
resources.rationale: Tennyson is one of the quintessential poets of the Victorian age. Like the society in which he lived, he grapples with the rapid change from the pastoral to the industrial.

resources.title: Teresa of Calcutta
resources.author: D. Jeanene Watson
resources.rationale: This missionary biography tells about the life of Mother Teresa (1910-1997) who dedicated her life to God and helping the poor in India.

resources.title: Tevye the Dairyman and The Railroad Stories
resources.author: Sholem Aleichem

resources.title: The 20th Century Children's Poetry Treasury
resources.author: Jack Prelutsky
resources.rationale: This is an illustrated anthology of 211 poems that represents the best the 20th century has to offer. It is a perfect fit for the time period we are studying this year.

resources.title: The Action Bible - Guess it Game
resources.author: Sergio Cariello

resources.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
resources.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
resources.rationale: More detective stories!

resources.title: The Adventures of the Mountain Men: True Tales of Hunting, Trapping, Fighting, Adventure, and Survival
resources.author: Stephen Brennan (Editor)
resources.rationale: Collection of source documents and writings from the early 1800s depicting life in the western wilderness.

resources.title: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer
resources.author: Mark Twain
resources.rationale: A classic work from time period author.
resources.note: Sensitive Content. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Adventurous Life of Myles Standish
resources.author: Cheryl Harness
resources.rationale: This engaging book about the life of Myles Standish, an English soldier, is a great way to study so many topics that are connected to him—the English monarchy, the Reformation, the Pilgrims, the Mayflower, Plymouth Colony, and Native Americans.  This book also has wonderful illustrations, detailed maps, and timelines that show students what else was happening around the world at this time.

resources.title: The Aeneid
resources.author: Virgil
resources.rationale: Classical epic poetry aligning with this year's Ancient History rotation.
resources.note: Excellent audiobook is also available on Amazon. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Aeneid for Boys and Girls
resources.author: Alfred Church
resources.rationale: This book tells the classic story of Aeneas, who escaped during the collapse of Troy and became an ancestor of Romulus and Remus, the mythical founders of Rome.

resources.title: The Age of Chivalry
resources.author: Thomas Bulfinch
resources.rationale: The Age of Chivalry by Thomas Bullfinch is a classic collection of myths and legends from medieval Europe, including the stories of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table, Robin Hood, and other heroic figures.

resources.title: The Age of Fable
resources.author: Thomas Bulfinch
resources.rationale: The Age of Fable contains mythological stories primarily from Greece and Rome, although it also includes some stories from Norse and Eastern traditions. The reading level is more challenging than the mythology stories assigned in the earlier grades.

resources.title: The Age of Walls
resources.author: Tim Marshall
resources.rationale: A thought-provoking look at the barriers between people around the globe and how geography, history, and politics all interact.

resources.title: The Amazing Stitching Handbook for Kids: 17 Embroidery Stitches
resources.author: Kristin Nicholas
resources.maySub: another sewing book.
resources.rationale: This book contains embroidery stitches that can be added to sewing projects.

resources.title: The American Patriot's Handbook
resources.author: George Grant
resources.rationale: Compilation of source documentation.

resources.title: The American Spirit (Audio)
resources.author: David McCullough
resources.maySub: the corresponding book.
resources.rationale: Speeches by noted historians generally following the historical rotation touching on topics of citizenship.

resources.title: The Ancient Egyptian World
resources.author: Eric H. Cline, Jill Rubalcaba
resources.rationale: This book is written by experts in their field yet accessible to students.  The authors tell the stories of the kings, queens, pharaohs, tomb builders, and ordinary citizens of ancient Egypt by tying in archeological finds and highlighting primary sources throughout the book.

resources.title: The Ancient Greek World
resources.author: Jennifer Roberts & Tracy Barrett
resources.rationale: This book is written by experts in their field who have a passion for their subject.  It tells about the people and events of ancient Greece while also including more recent archeological finds and highlighting primary sources. This book is a part of a great series that shows how the study of the past is a continuous process of weighing evidence, studying primary documents, and uncovering artifacts in order to illuminate what life was like for the people who lived before us.

resources.title: The Ancient Near Eastern World
resources.author: Amanda H. Podany & Marni McGee
resources.rationale: This book is written by experts in their field yet it is accessible to students. The authors tell the stories of the scribes, lawmakers, kings, queens, farmers, and priests who lived in the ancient lands of Mesopotamia, Israel, and Babylon by tying in archeological finds and highlighting primary sources throughout the book.

resources.title: The Apprentice's Companion for General Biology
resources.author: Ayala and Rogstad
resources.rationale: Teacher notes included.

resources.title: The Arrow Over the Door
resources.author: Joseph Bruchac
resources.rationale: Beginning the connection between literature and history for our students in Grades 3-4, this story drops readers into the summer of 1777 with young Samuel Russell. The British Army is approaching, and the Indians in the area seem ready to attack. Meanwhile, Stands Straight, a young Abenaki Indian scouting for King George, knows the Americans threaten his family and home. When Stands Straight's party enters the Quaker Meetinghouse where Samuel worships, the two boys share an encounter that neither will ever forget. Told in alternating viewpoints, _The Arrow over the Door_ is based on a true story.
resources.note: Grade 4 Students should choose this OR Seesaw Girl.

resources.title: The Art of Construction
resources.author: Mario Salvadori
resources.rationale: We love that this book provides hands-on activities for exploring the principles of engineering, allowing students to dip their toes into the engineering process with everyday materials.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting.

resources.title: The Art of Paint Marbling: Tips, techniques, and step-by-step instructions for creating colorful marbled art on paper
resources.author: Rene Eisenbart
resources.rationale: _The Art of Paint Marbling_ takes you through all the tools, techniques, and tips you need to create your own marbled artwork.
resources.note: There will be videos in the lesson plans to make this craft accessible for all ages.

resources.title: The Arts: A Visual Encyclopedia
resources.author: DK
resources.rationale: We will be using this as our spine throughout the course. It is a nice overview of global art history. This book was chosen due to its miniscule amount of nudity compared to other art books geared to teens.

resources.title: The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing, Vol. 1: The Pox Party (Option 1)
resources.author: M.T. Anderson
resources.rationale: Set in Revolutionary Boston, this thought-provoking novel takes place at a time when Patriots battled to win liberty while African slaves were entreated to risk their lives for a freedom they would never claim.
resources.note:
The first of two volumes, students will read this work during Term 2 and then may finish it and continue on with the series as interested in their own time.

Students may choose this book OR Singing Bird.

resources.title: The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin
resources.author: Benjamin Franklin
resources.rationale: This book contains much wisdom from an old man who looks back on an extraordinary life.

resources.title: The Backyard Beekeeper
resources.author: Kim Flottum
resources.rationale: Also available on Kindle and Audible.

resources.title: The Ballad of the White Horse
resources.author: G.K. Chesterton

resources.title: The Bandit of Ashley Downs: George Muller
resources.author: Dave & Neta Jackson

resources.title: The Bat Scientists
resources.author: Mary Kay Carson
resources.rationale: This book provides students with a closer look at an endangered species that might be right in their neighborhood. Follow Dr. Tuttle in his tireless work to understand and protect the bat and to maintain balance in the ecosystem.

resources.title: The Beggars' Bible
resources.author: Louise A. Vernon
resources.rationale: This historical fiction book is about John Wycliffe, the famous Oxford professor who translated the Bible into English in the 14th century.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read over the year.

resources.title: The Bible Explorer's Guide: 1,000 Amazing Facts and Photos
resources.author: Nancy I. Sanders

resources.title: The Bible Smuggler
resources.author: Louise A. Vernon
resources.rationale: This historical fiction book is about William Tyndale, a leading figure in the Reformation, who put himself in harm's way to translate the Bible into English in the early 16th century.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read over the year.

resources.title: The Bible Story Handbook
resources.author: John and Kim Walton
resources.rationale: This teacher resource from Bible scholar John Walton and his wife, Kim, provides helpful background information for teaching the Bible. In a succinct manner, they offer the biblical context, interpretational issues, and mistakes to avoid for numerous Biblical passages.
resources.note: This is a teacher resource to be read before the lesson. At times, the lesson plans may highlight certain sections. We encourage teachers to preview the selections and choose what ideas to share or discuss with their students.

resources.title: The Big Book of Canada
resources.author: Christopher Moore
resources.rationale: This is a survey of Canada. The book includes good maps and interesting information about each province, but the primary teaching tool for this course will be the lesson plans, which include much map work and outdoor exploration of geographical concepts.

resources.title: The Biola Advent & Lent Project
resources.author: CCCA
resources.rationale:
May sub Tsh Oxenreider Advent & Lent options.
Subscribe to the current seasonal calendar to receive daily email notifications going forward.

resources.title: The Biology Coloring Book
resources.author: Robert D. Griffin
resources.maySub: Teachers may substitute any games or activities on the topics covered in the General Biology text.
resources.rationale: In T_he Biology Coloring Boo_k, students learn about the basic processes of life and the interactions of living things within their environment.

resources.title: The Blacksmith
resources.author: Bobbie Kalman
resources.rationale: See how the village blacksmith made all kinds of useful things out out of iron during Colonial times.

resources.title: The Bondwoman's Narrative
resources.author: Hannah Crafts Ed. by Henry Louis Gates, Jr
resources.rationale: Believed to be the first novel written by a fugitive slave.
resources.note: Sensitive Content. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Book of Common Prayer
resources.rationale:
➜ May sub Phyllis Tickle's series: The Divine Hours OR Be Thou My Vision
Collection of prayers, psalms, and readings used in the church for several centuries.

resources.title: The Book of Indians
resources.author: Holling C. Holling
resources.rationale: Little Turtle lives on the cliffs of the desert. The other children make fun of him because he is slow and clumsy, so he plays by himself. One day, strangers approach Little Turtle's village. What Little Turtle does in response makes him a hero.
resources.note: PDF provided for member use only under Fair Use Copyright Law.

resources.title: The Book of Playground Songs & Rhymes
resources.author: John Feierabend
resources.maySub: earlier edition
resources.rationale: This book contains traditional children's songs and rhymes used to teach rhythm, jump rope, and hand-eye coordination.
resources.note: Song recordings will be available June 1.

resources.title: The Book of Rumi
resources.author: Rumi
resources.rationale: Short fables about common sense and everyday life by the famous Persian author and poet Rumi intrigue and instruct students and give them a glimpse of life in a medieval Persian and Islamic culture.
resources.note: Students will only read selections (younger students less and older students more) as some fables contain sensitive or inappropriate religious and/or moral content and will be skipped in the lesson plans.

resources.title: The Book of Song Dances
resources.author: John Feierabend
resources.maySub: earlier edition, but some dances have different page numbers.
resources.rationale: This book uses traditional songs, rhymes, and dances to teach children basic dance steps.
resources.note: Instructional videos will be available June 1.

resources.title: The Boreal Forest: A Year in the World's Largest Land Biome
resources.author: L.E. Carmichael

resources.title: The Boxcar Children series
resources.author: Gertrude Warner
resources.rationale: The Boxcar Children tells the story of four orphaned children, Henry, Jessie, Violet, and Benny. They create a home for themselves in an abandoned boxcar in the forest. They eventually meet their grandfather, who is a wealthy and kind man (although the children had believed him to be cruel). The children decide to live with the grandfather, who moves the beloved boxcar to his backyard so the children can use it as a playhouse.

resources.title: The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind
resources.author: William Kamkwamba & Bryan Mealer
resources.rationale: This wonderful story demonstrates the beauty, humanity, and accessibility of the engineering mindset.
resources.note: Choose this OR The Young Reader's Edition

resources.title: The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind, Young Reader's Edition
resources.author: William Kamkwamba & Bryan Mealer
resources.rationale: This wonderful story demonstrates the beauty, humanity, and accessibility of the engineering mindset.
resources.note: Choose this or the standard edition

resources.title: The Brendan Voyage
resources.author: Tim Severin
resources.rationale: Relying on the medieval text of St. Brendan, award-winning adventure writer Tim Severin painstakingly researched and built a boat identical to the leather curragh that carried Brendan on his epic voyage. Historical geography brings the time period to life.
resources.note: Read this OR Hawaiki Rising.

resources.title: The Bronze Bow
resources.author: Elizabeth George Speare
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Byzantine Empire (Exploring the Ancient World)
resources.author: Jennifer Ann Fretland VanVoorst
resources.rationale: The Byzantine Empire, which thrived from 395 to 1453, was a fascinating place. Its people thought of themselves as Romans, spoke Greek, and hailed from all across Europe and Asia. Centered in today's Istanbul, it was a Christian empire that preserved and developed Europe's intellectual heritage at a time when western Europe was in decline.

resources.title: The Call of The Wild
resources.author: Jack London
resources.maySub: Little Women by Alcott
resources.rationale: A classic work from time period author.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Catholic Church Through the Ages (2nd ed)
resources.author: John Vidmar
resources.rationale: Basic narrative of church history with a historical rather than doctrinal focus. Used with Shelley's text for a more complete overview of church history.
resources.note: Used for multiple history rotations.

resources.title: The Chemical Elements Coloring and Activity Book
resources.author: Ellen Johnston McHenry
resources.maySub: Teachers may substitute any periodic table game/resource that they prefer, such as the board game Periodic or Theodore Gray's The Elements.
resources.rationale: All 118 elements are included in coloring pages, with information about its discovery, examples of molecules it will form, and pictures of how the element might be used in industry, medicine, the military, research, and fine arts.  Also included are personalizable periodic table and a variety of games.

resources.title: The Chicago World's Fair
resources.author: Stanley Appelbaum
resources.rationale: Photographic record of the 1893 World's Fair.

resources.title: The Children’s Book of Virtues
resources.author: William Bennett
resources.rationale: Page 88 "The Indian Cinderella"

resources.title: The Children's Plutarch: Tales of the Greeks
resources.author: F. J. Gould

resources.title: The Children's Plutarch: Tales of the Romans
resources.author: F. J. Gould
resources.rationale: This is another author's retelling of Plutarch's Roman Lives, which can be compared with the ones in Stories From the History of Rome.

resources.title: The Chimney Sweep's Ransom
resources.author: Dave & Neta Jackson
resources.rationale: Using the fictionalized character of a young chimney sweep, this book introduces readers to John Wesley, the great English preacher from the 18th century.  This exciting story focuses on Wesley’s ministry to the coal miners and their families and shows how he lived out his faith through his actions and preaching of God’s love.

resources.title: The Chronological Guide to the Bible
resources.author: Thomas Nelson
resources.rationale: This book is a great companion for students as they read the Bible chronologically. It contains outlines and background information for the nine epochs of biblical history. Through illustrations, photos, and text, students learn about the manners and customs of the biblical world. Selections will be assigned as part of the lesson.

resources.title: The Collected Poems of W.B. Yeats
resources.author: W.B. Yeats

resources.title: The Colonial Cook
resources.author: Bobbie Kalman & Ellen Brown
resources.rationale: See the process of getting food on the table during Colonial times, including farming, storage, tools, technology, architecture, and people roles. Contains recipes.

resources.title: The Colosseum
resources.author: Keith Hopkins & Mary Beard
resources.rationale: History as seen through the lens of a famous ancient building.
resources.note: Sensitive Content. Optional read for interested students.

resources.title: The Complete Book of Chalk Lettering
resources.author: Valerie McKeehan
resources.rationale: This book includes lessons on various styles of lettering, in addition to project design, and adding dimension using chalk.
resources.note: Video tutorials provided with lesson plans.

resources.title: The Complete Book of Great Musicians: Handel
resources.author: Percy A. Scholes

resources.title: The Complete Book of the Great Musicians
resources.author: Percy A. Scholes
resources.rationale: Older book in friendly narrative style about many great composers throughout history. Selections used in lessons.

resources.title: The Complete Illustrated Children's Bible Atlas: Hundreds of Pictures, Maps, and Facts to Make the Bible Come Alive
resources.author: Harvest House Publishers

resources.title: The Complete Poems of Paul Laurence Dunbar
resources.author: Paul Laurence Dunbar
resources.rationale: Poems of an African-American poet, novelist, and playwright in the late 19th century

resources.title: The Craft of Research
resources.author: Wayne C. Booth
resources.rationale: A practical guide to research and more advanced writing.

resources.title: The Crossroads of Science and Faith: Answers to Exercises
resources.author: Kober, Benecchi, & Gossard
resources.maySub: ebook from lovingtruthbooks.com
resources.rationale: Contains answers to exercises included in the accompanying text.

resources.title: The Crossroads of Science and Faith: Astronomy Through a Christian Worldview
resources.author: Kober, Benecchi, & Gossard
resources.maySub: ebook from lovingtruthbooks.com
resources.rationale: Astronomy text with worldview discussions, which teachers may include as desired. Students that have read any Christian apologetics, such as Mere Christianity, may enjoy engaging in their own discussion and find that they do not need the additional support, however.

resources.title: The Cuckoo's Haiku: and Other Birding Poems
resources.author: Michael J. Rosen (author) & Stan Fellows (illustrator)

resources.title: The Curious Naturalist
resources.author: Sy Montgomery
resources.rationale: Fascinating essays on various nature study topics that give us more to look for and observe on our next nature walk.

resources.title: The Daughter of Time
resources.author: Josephine Tey
resources.rationale: Inspector Alan Grant of Scotland Yard, recuperating from a broken leg, becomes fascinated with a contemporary portrait of Richard III that bears no resemblance to the Wicked Uncle of history. A fascinating historical mystery novel and reflection on the nature of history and a perfect companion to Shakespeare's play which students will also read this year.

resources.title: The Death of the Hat: A Brief History of Poetry in 50 Objects
resources.author: Paul B. Janeczko
resources.rationale: The author takes readers on an interesting poetry journey from the Middle Ages to the present by presenting poems written about everyday objects.

resources.title: The Diary and Journal of David Brainerd
resources.author: David Brainerd (author), Jonathan Edwards (editor)

resources.title: The Discipline of Grace
resources.author: Jerry Bridges
resources.rationale: Devotional Literature

resources.title: The Discovery of the Americas
resources.author: Betsy & Giulio Maestro
resources.rationale: From the crossing of the Bering Land Bridge over thousands of years ago to the arrival of the Europeans, this picture book paints the early discoveries of America in grand strokes. It is used as a spine to complement the other books that talk about specific people and events.

resources.title: The Divine Hours, Volume II: Prayers for Autumn and Wintertime (Divine Hours)
resources.author: Phyllis Tickle
resources.rationale: ➜ May sub Book of Common Prayer OR Be Thou My Vision A contemporary collection of prayers, psalms, and readings.

resources.title: The Door in the Wall
resources.author: Marguerite de Angeli
resources.rationale: An unforgettable story set in medieval times that will ease students into reading lessons for themselves and broaden their understanding of the year's time period.

resources.title: The Dream Keeper and Other Poems
resources.author: Langston Hughes

resources.title: The Eagle
resources.author: Rosemary Sutcliff
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Earth Under Sky Bear's Feet
resources.author: Joseph Bruchac
resources.rationale: This short collection of Native American poems about various aspects of creation with beautiful illustrations by Thomas Locker develops students' appreciation for both poetry and history.

resources.title: The Egyptian Cinderella
resources.author: Shirley Climo
resources.rationale: 1 of 4 Cinderella picture books from Persia, Egypt, Ireland, and Korea.

resources.title: The Elements of Baking
resources.author: Katarina Cermelj
resources.rationale: This title is ideal for learning the science of baking, in which students will learn about and observe the properties of their ingredients, experiment with substitutions, and work toward their desired product.

resources.title: The Elements of Style
resources.author: Strunk & White
resources.rationale: Classic writing guide to help improve written communication.

resources.title: The Elephant Scientist
resources.author: Caitlin O'Connell and Donna M. Jackson
resources.rationale: Challenges arise when wild animals meet human communities. The scientist in this story not only observes elephants, but she also uses what she learns from them, along with what she already knows about sound waves, to collaborate with the local community to navigate such challenges.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The End of Empire: Attila the Hun & the Fall of Rome
resources.author: Christopher Kelly

resources.title: The Essential Writings of Ralph Waldo Emerson
resources.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
resources.note: ONLY Grade 11

resources.title: The Explorations of Captain James Cook in the Pacific: As Told by Selections of His Own Journals
resources.author: Captain James Cook & (editor) Grenfell Price
resources.rationale: Selections from the journals of Captain James Cook, a Scotland-born British naval commander who rose from humble beginnings to pilot three great eighteenth-century voyages of discover in the then practically uncharted Pacific Ocean.

resources.title: The Faithful Spy: Dietrich Bonhoeffer
resources.author: John Hendrix
resources.rationale: This biography will help readers understand the inner life of Bonhoeffer as well as the historical events surrounding him. The author uses graphic novel panels, a notebook-style layout, hand lettering, and word art to create a truly unique book.

resources.title: The Field Guide to Geology
resources.author: Lambert
resources.rationale: Basic principles of geology are laid out well with helpful illustrations.

resources.title: The First Thanksgiving
resources.author: Robert Tracy McKenzie
resources.rationale: Through the captivating story of the birth of this quintessentially American holiday, veteran historian Tracy McKenzie helps us to better understand the tale of America's origins―and for Christians, to grasp the significance of this story and those like it. McKenzie avoids both idolizing and demonizing the Pilgrims and calls us to love and learn from our flawed yet fascinating forebears.

resources.title: The Fool and the Heretic
resources.author: Todd Wood & Darrel Falk
resources.maySub: another selection from the Alveary Bookshelf.
resources.rationale: Two scientists with differing perspectives dialog respectfully about creation and evolution.  This is an excellent choice for students in contexts that perceive faith and science to threaten each other, as well as those interested in learning to have healthy discussion with those of differing viewpoints.
resources.note:
Choose this OR The Spirit of the Rainforest.

Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Audible.

resources.title: The Forest in the Tree
resources.author: Ailsa Wild, Aviva Reed, Briony Barr, & Gregory Crocetti
resources.rationale: This lovely picture book brings together important botanical and ecological topics within the context of a story.

resources.title: The Frog Scientist
resources.author: Pamela Turner
resources.rationale: Scientists now know that frogs are particularly sensitive to pollution. Readers join the work of scientists who are learning just how chemical run-off affects their life cycle. This text is a particularly good example of the relationship between field and laboratory work and introduces important facets of excellent experimental design "by the way."
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Gilded Page
resources.author: Mary Wellesley
resources.rationale: _The Gilded Page_ is the story of the written word in the manuscript age. Rich and surprising, it shows how the most exquisite objects ever made by human hands came from unexpected places.
resources.note: This book contains sensitive content. Lesson Plans will alert students and teachers to specific readings to allow for prereading, guidance, and discussion. The book does a great job of bringing the people behind the manuscripts to life.  A fuller understanding of the times is the result.

resources.title: The Girl Who Drew Butterflies: How Maria Merian's Art Changed Science
resources.author: Joyce Sidman
resources.rationale: One of the first naturalists to observe live insects directly, Maria Sibylla Merian was also one of the first to document the metamorphosis of the butterfly and the close relationships between insects and plants. In this richly illustrated nonfiction biography, readers meet the "mother" of ecology, a woman who flouted convention in the pursuit of knowledge.
resources.note: Available on Audible and Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally.

resources.title: The God of the Garden
resources.author: Andrew Peterson
resources.rationale: There’s a strong biblical connection between people and trees. They both come from dirt. They’re both told to bear fruit. In fact, arboreal language is so often applied to humans that it’s easy to miss, whether we're talking about family trees, passing along our seed, cutting someone off like a branch, being rooted to a place, or bearing the fruit of the Spirit. It’s hard to deny that trees mean something, theologically speaking.

resources.title: The Gospel of Jesus: The Four Gospels in a Single Complete Narrative
resources.rationale: _The Gospel of Jesus_ weaves the entirety of the four gospels into a continuous, highly readable harmony that is placed in chronological order.
resources.note: Use option one link to receive discount.

resources.title: The Great Adventure: An Illustrated History of Canada for Young Canadians
resources.author: D.J. Dickie

resources.title: The Great Big Book of Amazing Creative Lettering
resources.author: hinkler
resources.rationale: Lots of lettering ideas and different fonts.

resources.title: The Great Migration: An American Story
resources.author: Jacob Lawrence
resources.rationale: The plight of African Americans from the rural South to the urban North during the first half of the 20th century is captured through pictures and words.
resources.note:
Used briefly. You may wish to check out from the library. 
Preview first for sensitive children.

resources.title: The Great Quake: How the Biggest Earthquake in North America Changed Our Understanding of the Planet

resources.title: The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris

resources.rationale: McCullough's engaging account of Americans who traveled and lived in Paris during the nineteenth century. World events are seen through the eyes of these individuals and have a tremendous cultural impact.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Greatest Cities of Ancient Mesopotamia
resources.author: Charles Rivers
resources.rationale: Long before Alexandria was a city and even before Memphis and Babylon had attained greatness, the ancient Mesopotamian city of Ur stood foremost among ancient Near Eastern cities. Today, the greatness and cultural influence of Ur has been largely forgotten by most people, partially because its monuments have not stood the test of time the way other ancient culture’s monuments have. For instance, the monuments of Egypt were made of stone while those of Ur and most other Mesopotamian cities were made of mud brick and as will be discussed in this report, mud-brick may be an easier material to work with than stone but it also decays much quicker. The same is true to a certain extent for the written documents that were produced at Ur. No site better represents the importance of the Sumerians than the city of Uruk. Between the fourth and the third millennium BCE, Uruk was one of several city-states in the land of Sumer, located in the southern end of the Fertile Crescent, between the two great rivers of the Tigris and the Euphrates. Discovered in the late 19th century by the British archaeologist William Loftus, it is this site that has revealed much of what is now known of the Sumerian, Akkadian, and Neo-Sumerian people. Hattusa was different from the other major cities of the ancient Near East in one major respect: it was landlocked and not located on a major river. At first glance, such a situation may seem like a liability, which it was in terms of trade, but for the most part its central position meant that the Hittites could move their armies more efficiently from one theater of operations to another (Macqueen 2003, 56). As a landlocked capital, Hattusa was also safe from naval attacks from other kingdoms, so if the Hittites’ enemies wanted to invade their capital, they would have to trek through the middle of the kingdom to get there, which was most unlikely. As Hittite power grew during the Old Kingdom, the royal city of Hattusa became more important and even wealthier. From his citadel overlooking Hattusa, Hattusili I launched the first major Hittite attacks into the Near East, first conquering the cities between Hattusa and the Mediterranean (Macqueen 2003, 36). Although the Biblical accounts of the Assyrians are among the most interesting and are often corroborated with other historical sources, the Assyrians were much more than just the enemies of the Israelites and brutal thugs. Among all the cities that thrived in the ancient Near East, few can match the opulence and ostentatiousness of Nineveh, the capital of the Assyrian Empire for much of the seventh century BCE. During that time it became known for its mighty citadels, grand palaces, beautiful gardens, and even its zoos. In fact, the beauty of Nineveh, especially its gardens, impressed later writers so much that they assigned its gardens as one of the original Seven Wonders of the World, except unfortunately for Nineveh’s memory, the location was placed in Babylon. The confusion that assigned one of the Wonders of the World to Babylon instead of Nineveh is in fact a large part of Nineveh’s history – it was a great city during its time, but incessant warfare brought the metropolis to oblivion and eventually its history was forgotten or distorted. Today, Babylon has become a byword for greed, excess, and licentiousness, mostly due to its mention in the Bible, but a closer examination reveals that Babylon was so much more, and even perhaps the most important city in the ancient world. Ancient Babylon was home to great dynasties that produced some of the world’s most influential leaders, most notably Hammurabi and Nebuchadnezzar.

resources.title: The Hands-On Equations Verbal Problems Book
resources.author: Hands-On Equations
resources.rationale: Contains word problems wherein students apply what they learned in their lessons to real-world situations.

resources.title: The Harvest Birds/Los pájaros de la cosecha
resources.author: Blanca Lopez de Mariscal
resources.rationale: This is a story for beginning readers in Spanish that showcases the traditions of rural Mexico.

resources.title: The Harvey Girls: Women Who Opened the West
resources.author: Lesley Poling-Kempes

resources.title: The Hidden Beauty of Seeds and Fruits

resources.title: The Hidden Life of Trees: The Illustrated Edition
resources.author: Peter Wohlleben
resources.rationale: This title provides students with current scientific information and human connections to support their knowledge about trees both as individuals and within their context.  The beautiful photography in this piece of botany literature is inspiring and supportive.

resources.title: The History of Rasselas, Prince of Abyssinia
resources.author: Samuel Johnson

resources.title: The Hive Detectives: Chronicle of a Honey Bee Catastrophe
resources.author: Loree Griffin Burns
resources.rationale: This book shows concepts from ecology, mathematics, and chemistry as it invites students into conversation on an important current issue.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with advanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Honour Drum
resources.author: Cheryl Bear and Tim Huff
resources.rationale: Written as a partnership between two friends -- an Indigenous woman and a non-Indigenous man -- _The Honour Drum _introduces children to the history, stories, traditions, and symbols that have been meaningful to Indigenous people from the distant past right up to today. Its aim is to foster understanding, empathy, and appreciation, and to spark meaningful conversations with your children.

resources.title: The House of the Seven Gables
resources.author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
resources.rationale: A classic work from time period author.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
resources.author: Rebecca Skloot
resources.rationale: Biography of the woman whose stolen cells shaped the development of today's medicine.
resources.note:
Sensitive Content. 

Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting, Audible, and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Incredible yet True Adventures of Alexander von Humboldt
resources.author: Volker Mehnert
resources.rationale: A curious and adventurous Alexander von Humboldt dares to travel into unexplored areas of South America and venture north to parts of Mexico, the Caribbean, and the eastern coast of America. Along with his companions, he details the amazing new continent and beyond, rich with geographical landmarks and new biological/ecological discoveries.

resources.title: The Inventor's Secret: What Thomas Edison Told Henry Ford
resources.author: Suzanne Slade

resources.title: The IVP Atlas of Bible History
The Journey That Saved Curious George
resources.author: Louise W. Borden

resources.title: The Kid's Book of Canada's Railway
resources.author: Deborah Hodge

resources.title: The Kidnapped Prince: The Life of Olaudah Equiano
resources.author: Ann Cameron
resources.rationale: This book, adapted from Equiano's autobiography, tells the true story of a boy who was kidnapped in Africa and sold into slavery, only to buy his freedom as an adult.

resources.title: The Kids Book of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada
resources.author: Diane Silvey
resources.rationale: This well-researched and beautifully illustrated book introduces children to traditions and cultures of seven Indigenous groups at the time just before first contact with Europeans. The detailed illustrations are based on current research, museum artifacts, historical paintings, and written descriptions from the time, and they provide a lively and engaging representation of the past.

resources.title: The Kids Book of Canada
resources.author: Barbara Greenwood
resources.rationale: This book gives an engaging overview of Canada's ten provinces and three territories and includes maps, geographical features, important facts, symbols, significant people, places, and events.

resources.title: The Kids Book of Canadian History
resources.author: Carlotta Hacker
resources.rationale: This book brings Canada's history to life with engaging illustrations, helpful maps, and a narrative that keeps the complex events of our nation's past straightforward enough for even the youngest historians.

resources.title: The Kids' Guide to Digital Photography: How to Shoot, Save, Play With & Print Your Digital Photos
resources.author: Jenni Bidner

resources.title: The King's Fifth
resources.author: Scott O'Dell
resources.rationale: This piece of suspenseful historical fiction takes students into the world of the conquistadors with Esteban, a seventeen-year-old cartographer.

resources.title: The Last Mapmaker
resources.author: Christina Soontornvat
resources.rationale: A tale about character, integrity, and friendship in a time of exploration, mapping, and conquest. This book draws students into another world with rich storytelling and subtly enriches their historical studies as well because of its thematic relevance.

resources.title: The Laws Guide to Drawing Birds
resources.author: John Muir Laws
resources.rationale: Promotes seeing and capturing on paper the wonders of birds.

resources.title: The Laws Guide to Nature Drawing and Journaling
resources.author: John Muir Laws
resources.rationale: Very helpful for beginning or advanced students of nature study.

resources.title: The Legend of Hobbomock: The Sleeping Giant
resources.author: Jason J. Marchi
resources.rationale: This is the Quinnipiac tribal legend of how the Sleeping Giant landform in Hamden, Connecticut came to look like a giant man sleeping on his back.

resources.title: The Legend of the Bluebonnet: An Old Tale of Texas
resources.author: Tomie dePaola
resources.rationale: When a killing drought threatens the existence of the tribe, a courageous Comanche girl sacrifices her most beloved possession--and the Great Spirit's answer results not only in much-needed rain but a special gift in return.

resources.title: The Legend of the Indian Paintbrush
resources.author: Tomie dePaola
resources.rationale: In spring, the hills and meadows of Texas and Wyoming are ablaze with the reds, oranges, and yellows of the Indian Paintbrush. How this striking plant received its name is told in an old Indian legend.

resources.title: The LEGO® Architect
resources.author: Tom Alphin
resources.rationale: Travel through the history of architecture in _The LEGO Architect_. Learn about styles like Art Deco, Modernism, and High-Tech, and find inspiration in galleries of LEGO models. Then take a turn building 12 models in a variety of styles.

resources.title: The LEGO® Engineer
resources.author: Jeff Friesen
resources.rationale: LEGO® bricks meet _The Way Things Work_ in this fun, informative tour of the world of engineering, from the creative mind of expert LEGO® builder Jeff Friesen.

resources.title: The Life and Times of the Honeybee
resources.author: Charles Micucci

resources.title: The Life of Jesus: Harmonized Gospels
resources.author: Brian Simmons
resources.rationale: A short and readable consecutive “narrative” account of the life of Christ. The four gospels are combined, with notations on the compilations of the verses, into roughly chronological order.

resources.title: The Life We're Looking For: Reclaiming Relationship in a Technological World
resources.author: Andy Crouch
resources.rationale: A deeply reflective primer on creating meaningful connections, rebuilding abundant communities, and living in a way that engages our full humanity in an age of unprecedented anxiety and loneliness.

resources.title: The Lightning Dreamer: Cuba's Greatest Abolitionist
resources.author: Margarita Engle
resources.rationale: Poetic fictionalized account of famous Cuban abolitionist and author Gertrudis Gómez Avellaneda.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
resources.author: C. S. Lewis
resources.maySub: King of the Wind (see Grades 5-6) or another in the Narnia series if students have already read The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe
resources.rationale: This piece of classic literature by C.S. Lewis was chosen to foster students' moral formation and love for a well-told story.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Lost Art of Reading Nature's Signs
resources.author: Tristan Gooley
resources.rationale: Helpful for growing your outside observational skills.

resources.title: The Lost Colony of Roanoke
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: The Lost Colony of Roanoke is one of the most puzzling mysteries in America's history. In 1587, 115 colonists sailed to the new world, eager to build the brand new Cittie of Raleigh, only to disappear practically without a trace. This book tells about one of the first colonies of America and the mystery that surrounds it.

resources.title: The Lost World of the Old Ones
resources.author: David Roberts
resources.rationale: In this thrilling story of intellectual and archaeological discovery, David Roberts recounts his exploits in search of spectacular prehistoric ruins and rock art panels known to very few modern travelers. His adventures range across Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, and southwestern Colorado, and illuminate the mysteries of the Ancestral Puebloans and their contemporary neighbors the Mogollon and Fremont, as well as of the more recent Navajo and Comanche.
resources.note: Grades 10 & 11 choose Manteo's World OR The Lost World of the Old Ones. Grade 12 reads both.

resources.title: The Making of a Poem
resources.author: Eavan Boland, Mark Strand
resources.rationale: Students read this anthology to learn how to study the characteristics and history of various poetic forms and then enjoy a number of examples from poets across the years, including many from this year's time period.

resources.title: The Man Who Invented Christmas directed
resources.author: Bharat Nalluri
resources.rationale: Movie based on the biographical novel by Les Standiford telling how A Christmas Carol was written.

resources.title: The Man Who Laid the Egg
resources.author: Louise Vernon
resources.rationale: "Erasmus laid the egg that Luther hatched," is what the people said. This historical fiction story tells about the life of Erasmus (1466-1536), a Dutch scholar known for producing a new Latin translation of the New Testament that challenged some of the older interpretations of the previous translation and stirred up some controversy with church leaders. Many of his ideas influenced future Reformers.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read over the year.

resources.title: The Map That Changed the World
resources.author: Simon Winchester
resources.rationale: A biography of a famous geologist.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting, Audible, and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Master Puppeteer
resources.author: Katherine Paterson
resources.rationale: Enjoy a story set in Japan in the 1700s!

resources.title: The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit
resources.author: M
resources.rationale: M's Theorems are not your average Sudoku or crossword puzzles. They're each completely unique, beautifully illustrated, "escape room"-like puzzles that’ll have you decrypting messages and tackling creative brain-teasers.

resources.title: The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood
The Milkweed Lands: An Epic Story of One Plant: Its Nature and Ecology
resources.author: Eric Lee-Mader
resources.rationale: Delve into the fascinating role of this often-overlooked plant in a wide variety of ecosystems.  A collaboration between a noted ecologist and an award-winning botanical illustrator, this text will inspire readers in their own special studies.

resources.title: The Mouse and the Motorcycle series
resources.author: Beverly Cleary
resources.rationale: With Ralph S. Mouse behind the handlebars of his favorite toy motorcycle, there's no telling what readers will encounter.

resources.title: The Mysterious Voyage of Captain Kidd
resources.author: A.B.C. Whipple
resources.rationale: This is a biographical story about the late 17th-century Captain William Kidd, who was commissioned as a privateer, only to be accused of piracy. His adventures took him through ports and coasts along the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. By following Captain Kidd on his last mission voyage, students will discover the islands and places that were vital to merchants sailing in the West Indies and the Caribbean.

resources.title: The Narrative of Lunsford Lane, Formerly of Raleigh, N. C.
resources.author: Lunsford Lane

resources.title: The Naturalist's Notebook
resources.author: Wheelwright and Heinrich
resources.rationale: A great 5-year Book of Firsts notebook where students can record the first frost, snowfall, tulip, bluebird, etc. A great complement to your Nature Notebook.

resources.title: The Naturalist's Notebook
resources.author: Nathaniel T. Wheelwright & Bernd Heinrich
resources.rationale: Become a more attentive observer and deepen your appreciation for the natural world. The unique five-year calendar format of _The Naturalist’s Notebook_ helps you create a long-term record and point of comparison for memorable events.

resources.title: The Nature Obscura: A City's Hidden Natural World
resources.author: Kelly Brenner
resources.rationale: Help for nature study in the city!

resources.title: The Nature of English Poetry
resources.author: Harris
resources.rationale: The delightful next step into the sights and sounds of poetry.

resources.title: The Nature of Yosemite: A Visual Journey
resources.author: Robb Hirsch
resources.rationale: This book offers stunning photography and wonderful descriptions of Yosemite that captures the wonder and awe of that great national park.

resources.title: The New Americans
resources.author: Betsy Maestro
resources.rationale: _The New Americans_ is the story of the colonists—the more than two hundred thousand new Americans— who came over from Europe and struggled to build a home for themselves in a new world. This book is used as a spine to provide context to complement the other books about specific people and events.

resources.title: The New Manners and Customs of Bible Times
resources.author: Ralph Gower
resources.rationale: Through illustrations, photos, and clear explanations, this best-selling reference book shows what life was life in Bible times and makes Scripture come to life as students imagine living in that time and place. We will assign certain sections before or after Bible readings that will help students understand the context of the passage and gain more insight into the culture and geography of Israel.

resources.title: The Octopus Scientists: Exploring the Mind of a Mollusk
resources.author: Sy Montgomery
resources.rationale: This book provides students with a closer look at a creature from the family Mollusca. With respect and persistence, the author pursues the mysterious and fascinating octopus - and shares all that she learns with us, of course!
resources.note: Available on Audible and Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally.

resources.title: The Odyssey
resources.author: Homer translated by Robert Fagles
resources.maySub: another edition of Homer's Odyssey
resources.rationale: Homer's famous epic telling the story of Odysseus' return home in the aftermath of the Trojan war.
resources.note: We like Fagle's translation for it's vivid imagery, lyrical poetry, and clean formatting, but many excellent editions of Homer's work exist, and lesson plans will include chapter info so that audiobooks or alternate translations may be substituted if desired.

resources.title: The Odyssey: A Norton Critical Edition
resources.author: Homer (author), Emily Wilson (translator)

resources.title: The Omnivore's Dilemma: Young Readers Edition
resources.author: Michael Pollan

resources.title: The Parallel Westminster Shorter Catechism Handbook
resources.author: Caroline Weerstra
resources.rationale:
May sub one of the other catechisms.
A basic summary of scriptural truths used in the church for centuries.

resources.title: The Parallel Westminster Shorter Catechism Handbook
resources.author: John Piper
resources.rationale:
May sub one of the other catechisms.
A basic summary of scriptural truths used in the church for centuries.

resources.title: The Parthenon
resources.author: Mary Beard
resources.rationale: History as seen through the lens of a famous ancient building.

resources.title: The Pilgrims of Plimoth
resources.author: Marcia Sewall
resources.rationale: In a text that mirrors their language and thoughts, Marcia Sewall has masterfully recreated the coming of the pilgrims to the New World, and the daily flow of their days during the first years in the colony they called Plimoth.

resources.title: The Plant Hunters: The Adventures of the World's Greatest Botanical Explorers
resources.author: Carolyn Fry
resources.rationale: Eighteenth- and nineteenth-century explorers were determined to find and collect new and unusual specimens, no matter what the cost. This book explores the history of plant hunting.

resources.title: The Plutarch Project Primer: Publicola (Revised)
resources.author: Anne White
resources.rationale: Students will read about Publicola, one of the first consuls of the Roman Republic. The Plutarch Primer includes vocabulary, discussion questions, and other aids for students and parents/teachers, plus edited text for Plutarch's Life of Publicola. It is designed especially for those who are new to the study of Plutarch. Lesson plans will include additional guidance.

resources.title: The Plutarch Project Vol.1 (Revised Edition)
resources.author: Anne White
resources.rationale: Anne White has broken up the Lives into reasonable sections with suitable omissions for length and content. She also included study helps to aid with understanding.

resources.title: The Plutarch Project Vol.7
resources.author: Anne White
resources.rationale: Students will read about the lives of Pompey and Themistocles. Anne White has broken up the Lives into reasonable sections with suitable omissions for length and content. She also included study helps to aid with understanding. Lesson plans will offer guidance as well.

resources.title: The Plutarch Project Volume Five (Revised)
resources.author: Anne White
resources.rationale: Students will read about the lives of Alexander and Timoleon. Anne White has broken up the Lives into reasonable sections with suitable omissions for length and content. She also included study helps to aid with understanding. Lesson plans will offer guidance as well.

resources.title: The Plutarch Project Volume Three (Revised)
resources.author: Anne White
resources.rationale: Students will read about the lives of Julius Caesar, Agis and Cleomenes, and the Gracchi. Anne White has broken up the Lives into reasonable sections with suitable omissions for length and content. She also included study helps to aid with understanding. Lesson plans will offer guidance as well.

resources.title: The Poems of Phillis Wheatley: With Letters and a Memoir
resources.author: Phillis Wheatley
resources.maySub: free links to individual poems and documents online.
resources.rationale: This is a nice edition of Phillis Wheatley's writings as they were originally published, which helps students befriend this famous American poet and understand her work in context. Younger students read more accessible selections while older students will read most of the book.

resources.title: The Poppy Lady: Moina Belle Michael and Her Tribute to Veterans
resources.author: Barbara Walsh
resources.rationale: This picture book tells the story of Moina Belle Michael, a schoolteacher from Georgia, who established the red poppy as the enduring symbol to remember the veterans. The historical events leading up to World War I and their effect on the lives of men and women are introduced in an age-appropriate way.
resources.note: Used briefly. You may wish to check out from the library.

resources.title: The Portable Medieval Reader
resources.author: James Bruce Ross & Mary Martin McLaughlin
resources.rationale: This anthology assembles an entire chorus of those voices—of kings, warriors, prelates, merchants, artisans, chroniclers, and scholars—that together convey a lively, intimate impression of a world that might otherwise seem immeasurably alien.

resources.title: The Power of Geography: Ten Maps that Reveal the Future of Our World
resources.author: Tim Marshall
resources.rationale: A thought-provoking look at ten regions set to shape global politics and how geography, history, and current events all interact.
