resources.title: The President and the Freedom Fighter: Abraham Lincoln, Frederick Douglass, and Their Battle to Save America's Soul
resources.author: Brian Kilmeade
resources.rationale: The story of a friendship that changed the country.

resources.title: The Press in the French Revolution: a selection of documents taken from the press of the Revolution for the years 1789-1794
resources.author: John Gilchrest
resources.rationale: A selection of articles and documents published during the French Revolution. Fascinating to get a sense of what was happening on the "street" level.

resources.title: The Puritan Dilemma: The Story of John Winthrop
resources.author: Edmund Morgan
resources.maySub: earlier edition
resources.rationale: A very readable biography that brings the time period to life.

resources.title: The Quartet: Orchestrating the Second American Revolution, 1783-1789
resources.author: Joseph J. Ellis
resources.rationale: This book focuses on four influential men in the era between the Revolution and the formation of the federal government.

resources.title: The Race to Save the Lord God Bird (Option 2)
resources.author: Phillip Hoose
resources.rationale: The fascinating story of the Ivory-Bill Woodpecker of the southern US and Cuba and the impact of the events of 1650-1800 on its habitat.
resources.note:
This is the revised edition of the original book published in 2004.

Choose this book OR Chasing Venus

resources.title: The Ramayana: A Shortened Modern Prose Version of the Indian Epic
resources.author: R.K. Narayan
resources.rationale: The greatest Indian epic, one of the world's supreme masterpieces of storytelling which became popular in the 4th century B.C. Retold in this condensed English prose-version by a master writer, this quest tale takes students on a journey with a prince who must leave his kingdom and overcome obstacles before coming home.

resources.title: The Random House Book of Poetry for Children
resources.author: Jack Prelutsky
resources.rationale: This is a book filled with funny and illuminating poems for kids, personally selected by the nation's first Children's Poet Laureate, Jack Prelutsky, and illustrated by Arnold Lobel of Frog and Toad fame. Collected from authors across the centuries, this anthology invites children to experience the delight and wonder of words.

resources.title: The Reasons for Seasons
resources.author: Gail Gibbons
resources.rationale: This book is a great introduction to seasons, the earth's orbit, and axial tilt.
resources.note: Teachers may wish to check this book out from the library rather than purchase it, as it is only used for a couple of lessons. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Red Palace
resources.author: June Hur
resources.rationale: _The Red Palace_ is a thrilling mystery that transports students to the secretive, dangerous world of the eighteenth-century Korean royal palace. The vivid descriptions, atmospheric writing, and carefully researched details about Korean culture and practices during this time period create a captivating world with memorable characters and a gripping plot. While on the surface the book is a page-turning detective story, the narrative probes deeper questions about identity, family, and revenge versus justice.

resources.title: The Red Sash
resources.author: Jean E. Pendziwol
resources.rationale: _The Red Sash_ portrays what life was like for a Metis family living near the fur-trading post of Fort William on Lake Superior at the dawn of the nineteenth century. The story takes place during Rendezvous, when voyageurs returned to Fort William with the furs they received in trade with Indigenous people, and where they meet merchants from the North West Company. Vivid and historically accurate illustrations give an authentic picture of life at this busy fur-trading post.

resources.title: The Remarkable Voyages of Captain Cook
resources.author: Rhoda Blumberg
resources.rationale: This book follows Captain James Cook and his crew on all three voyages of discovery, describing in detail his encounters with the indigenous people of Australia and the Pacific Islands.

resources.title: The Revenge of the Forty-Seven Samurai
resources.author: Erik C. Haugaard
resources.rationale: This is a retelling of one of Japan’s most legendary true stories—a tale of honor, loyalty, and vengeance. Set in 18th-century Japan, this historical account follows a group of masterless samurai, who seek to avenge the unjust death of their lord. This book immerses readers in the world of feudal Japan, exploring the values and conflicts that defined the samurai way of life.

resources.title: The Riddle of the Rosetta Stone
resources.author: James Cross Giblin
resources.rationale: This tells the story of soldiers in Napoleon's army discovering the Rosetta Stone in 1799 in Egypt and the years it took for scholars to decipher the mysterious hieroglyphs. This unlocked Egyptian history to the world and allowed people to understand this ancient culture.

resources.title: The Riddle of the Tongue-Stones: How Blessed Nicolas Steno Uncovered the Hidden History of the Earth
resources.author: Thomas Salerno

resources.title: The River Of Grace: A Story Of John Calvin
resources.author: Joyce McPherson
resources.rationale: This is a biography of John Calvin, who learned about the Bible and its message of salvation by faith while at university. After his conversion, he became a leader of the Protestants in France until he was driven out by persecution. He spoke and wrote prolifically, carrying on the message of the Reformation, including many commentaries and his "Institutes of the Christian Religion."
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read.

resources.title: The Road Not Taken and Other Poems
resources.author: Robert Frost

resources.title: The Road to There: Mapmakers and Their Stories
resources.author: Val Ross
resources.rationale: Unexpected stories of mapmakers from the current history rotation.

resources.title: The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt
resources.author: John Ray
resources.rationale: Capturing the drama of the race to decode this key to the ancient past, John Ray traces the paths pursued by the British polymath Thomas Young and Jean-Francois Champollion, the "father of Egyptology" ultimately credited with deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs. He shows how Champollion "broke the code" and explains more generally how such deciphering is done, as well as its critical role in the history of Egyptology. Concluding with a chapter on the political and cultural controversy surrounding the Stone, the book also includes an appendix with a full translation of the Stone's text.
resources.note: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

resources.title: The Rough-Face Girl
resources.author: Rafe Martin
resources.rationale: Compare this Algonquin Cinderella story to the Ojibwa story.

resources.title: The Round Book
resources.author: Margaret Read MacDonald, Winifred Jaeger
resources.rationale: Suitable for all ages.

resources.title: The Royal Kingdoms of Ghana, Mali, and Songhay
resources.author: Patricia McKissack, Fredrick McKissack
resources.rationale: For more than a thousand years, from A.D. 500 to 1700, the medieval kingdoms of Ghana, Mali, and Songhay grew rich on the gold, salt, and slave trade that stretched across Africa. This book reveals the glory of these forgotten empires while inviting readers to share in the inspiring process of historical recovery that is taking place today.
resources.note: Some sections will be skipped due to time and some sensitive content. Follow page numbers in lesson plans.

resources.title: The Sand-Reckoner
resources.author: Gillian Bradshaw
resources.rationale: Read a fictionalized historical biography of a portion of Archimedes' life, set in 264 B.C., as he returns home from Alexandria, as Syracuse is gearing up for war with Rome. This is a fascinating look into the man and his times.

resources.title: The Scarlet Letter
resources.author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
resources.maySub: another edition
resources.rationale: An American classic set in the time of the Puritans.
resources.note: We recommend this beautiful edition annotated by Karen Swallow Prior because of its helpful introduction, annotations, and thoughtful discussion questions from a Christian perspective.

resources.title: The Scarlet Pimpernel
resources.author: Emmuska Orczy
resources.rationale: The mysterious Scarlet Pimpernel is working to bring French aristocrats to freedom in England.

resources.title: The Secret Life of the Little Red Fox
resources.author: Laurence Pringle

resources.title: The Secret Life of the Skunk
resources.author: Laurence Pringle
resources.maySub: any life-giving picture book preferred by the teacher that is about a mammal
resources.rationale: This beautiful picture book illuminates the life of a common but less-often-observed creature.  It is a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.

resources.title: The Sibley Guide to Trees
resources.author: David Allen Sibley
resources.rationale: Botany students use this guide to study tree families from across North America and to consider various aspects of tree anatomy.
resources.note: For local tree identification, students will still want one or more of the local/regional field guides.

resources.title: The Sign of the Beaver
resources.author: Elizabeth George Speare
resources.rationale: Thirteen-year-old Matt is left alone at the frontier cabin he helped his father build, while his father goes to get the rest of the family. After losing his gun--his only means of hunting food and protecting himself--he meets members of a neighboring tribe and learns about survival and the relationship between the white settlers and the Native Americans.

resources.title: The Silk Roads: A New History of the World
resources.author: Peter Frankopan
resources.rationale: A fascinating look at the interlocking history of the East and the West.
resources.note: This book is used in several rotations and is a more advanced version of the book used last year in Grade 9. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Silk Roads: The Extraordinary History That Created Your World – Illustrated Edition
resources.author: Peter Frankopan
resources.rationale: An illustrated young person's version of Frankopan's book provides a narrative overview of events in specific time periods. This book is used in Grades 7-9 in both World and Ancient History for multiple history rotations.
resources.note: Make sure to buy the Illustrated version.

resources.title: The Spectator
resources.author: Joseph Addison & Sir Richard Steele
resources.rationale: One of the first English newspapers.

resources.title: The Spirit of Canada: Canada's Story in Legends, Fiction, Poems, and Songs
resources.author: Barbara Hehner
resources.rationale: Organized thematically, this beautiful anthology encompasses a wide variety of voices and stories that reflect Canada's past and present. It is an excellent accompaniment to Canadian history and literature, as it contains many different genres: poems, songs, letters, legends, stories, folk tales, historical accounts, and more.
resources.note: Canadian students should purchase this book and NOT American Tall Tales for the Tall Tales/Fables course.

resources.title: The Spirit of the Rainforest
resources.author: Dr. Rosa Vasquez Espinoza
resources.maySub: another selection from the Alveary Bookshelf.
resources.rationale: A leading scientist explores the synergy between indigenous knowledge and classical science in this courageous and deeply spiritual adventure. This is an excellent choice for students who are secure in the harmony between faith and science and would benefit from a living example in their modern world, as well as those interested in indigenous voices.
resources.note:
Choose this OR The Fool and the Heretic.

Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Audible.

resources.title: The Stars: A New Way to See Them
resources.author: H.A. Rey
resources.rationale: Practical guide to stargazing

resources.title: The Story of Canada
resources.author: Janet Lunn, Christopher Moore
resources.maySub: previous edition. Page numbers will differ from lesson plans.
resources.rationale: Canadian history is told through rich narrative, recreations of daily life, folk tales, and fascinating facts.

resources.title: The Story of Paintings: A History of Art for Children
resources.author: Mick Manning

resources.title: The Story of Science: Aristotle Leads the Way
resources.author: Joy Hakim
resources.rationale: This series situates facts and theories within their historical, political, and cultural context.  The author tells the story of science as a process of developing knowledge that is intimately tied to human society. Ms. Hakim challenges readers to consider differing viewpoints, so as to understand science with uncommon wholeness.
resources.note:
Sensitive content. Teachers should pre-read and plan how to handle potentially controversial topics.

Available on Kindle and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Story of Science: Einstein Adds a New Dimension
resources.author: Joy Hakim
resources.rationale: This series situates facts and theories within their historical, political, and cultural context.  The author tells the story of science as a process of developing knowledge that is intimately tied to human society. Ms. Hakim challenges readers to consider differing viewpoints, so as to understand science with uncommon wholeness.
resources.note:
Sensitive content. Parents should pre-read and plan how to handle potentially controversial topics.

Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Story of Science: Newton At the Center
resources.author: Joy Hakim
resources.rationale: This series situates facts and theories within their historical, political, and cultural context.  The author tells the story of science as a process of developing knowledge that is intimately tied to human society. Ms. Hakim challenges readers to consider differing viewpoints, so as to understand science with uncommon wholeness.
resources.note:
Sensitive content. Parents should pre-read and plan how to handle potentially controversial topics.

Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Story of the Amistad
resources.author: Emma Gelders Sterne
resources.rationale: This is the gripping true story of the 1839 uprising on the sea and the high-profile trial that followed. Were the Africans murderous mutineers and the rightful property of Spain, or were they free men taken illegally from their homes and only defending themselves?

resources.title: The Story of the Earth in 25 Rocks
resources.author: Prothero
resources.rationale: A fascinating look at what the rocks tell us according to a well-known expert in his field.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Audible.

resources.title: The Story of the Persian War
resources.author: Alfred J. Church
resources.rationale: This is a history of Darius the Great’s invasion of Greece, now known as the First Persian War.

resources.title: The Story of the World Vol.3: Early Modern Times (Revised Edition)
resources.author: Susan Wise Bauer
resources.rationale: This book outlines significant events on every continent and includes maps, illustrations, and tales from the various cultures.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Story of the World Vol.4: The Modern Age (Revised Edition)
resources.author: Susan Wise Bauer
resources.rationale: This series offers a comprehensive overview of world history that is up-to-date and pleasant to read.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
resources.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
resources.rationale: A classic work from time period author.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Student Bible Atlas, Revised Edition
resources.author: Tim Dowley
resources.maySub: other Bible atlas, though page numbers in lesson plans will not match.
resources.rationale: This is a simple, inexpensive Bible atlas that provides full-page maps of the biblical lands of the Old and New Testaments. In Bible lessons, students will be directed to look at specific pages. This resource is for Grades 3-8 ONLY.

resources.title: The Student Lab Report Handbook
resources.author: John Mays
resources.rationale: Used for Physics and Chemistry.  Especially helpful for those that have little experience keeping a lab notebook.

resources.title: The Sword of the Spirit: The Story of William Tyndale
resources.author: Joyce McPherson
resources.rationale: If you want to understand the course of the Reformation in England, then the story starts with Tyndale: student, scholar, translator, printer, smuggler, and witness to the truth of the gospel of Jesus Christ. The author's retelling of his life is meticulously researched and engages students' minds and hearts.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read.

resources.title: The Tales of Uncle Remus: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit
resources.author: Julius Lester
resources.rationale: Whether he is besting Brer Fox or sneaking into Mr. Man's garden, Brer Rabbit demonstrates that brains are better than brawn, along with other life lessons. These classic tales from the African American tradition are full of humor and creativity, and Julius Lester's retelling makes them a delight for readers today.

resources.title: The Taming of the Shrew
resources.author: William Shakespeare
resources.rationale: This play is one of Shakespeare's most popular comedies.

resources.title: The Taming of the Shrew (Audio recording)
resources.author: Arkangel
resources.maySub: Librivox recording
resources.rationale: This audio recording can help students access the wit and insight of Shakespeare's prose.

resources.title: The Tech-Wise Family
resources.author: Andy Crouch
resources.rationale: Making conscientious choices about technology is more than just using internet filters and determining screen time limits. It's about developing wisdom, character, and courage in the way we use digital media rather than accepting technology's promises of ease, instant gratification, and the world's knowledge at our fingertips. Helpful for students to consider as they head into adulthood.

resources.title: The Tempest (Audio recording)
resources.author: Arkangel
resources.maySub: Librivox recording

resources.title: The Things We Make
resources.author: Bill Hammack, Ph.D
resources.rationale: From medieval cathedrals to modern soda cans, this book will help learners grasp 'the engineering method' and notice it working all around them.
resources.note: There is some mild sensitive content in Ch.2 for which support will be provided in lesson 1.  Teachers may choose to preview this chapter in advance.

resources.title: The Three Little Pigs
resources.author: Teresa Mlawer
resources.rationale: This simplified retelling of a classic folk tale includes both English and Spanish text on each page.

resources.title: The Tornado Scientist
resources.author: Mary Kay Carson
resources.rationale: In this captivating story, readers follow a tornado scientist, learn about her life, her work, and her passion to save lives by improving our understanding of the weather.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Trailblazing Life of Daniel Boone and How Early Americans Took to the Road
resources.author: Cheryl Harness
resources.rationale: A true pioneer and survivalist, Daniel Boone explores early 18th-century North American wilderness and settlements. Along the way, he comes across many adventures and meets interesting people who will help define a new country and certain states. This book has wonderful illustrations, maps, primary-source quotations, and a timeline that runs at the bottom of each page.

resources.title: The Tree is Older Than You Are: A Bilingual Gathering of Poems & Stories from Mexico with Paintings by Mexican Artists
resources.author: Naomi Shihab Nye
resources.rationale: Contains poems in Spanish and English to give students deeper insight into the culture.

resources.title: The True Story of Pocahontas
resources.author: Dr. Linwood "Little Bear" Custalow, Angela L. Daniel “Silver Star”
resources.rationale: _The True Story of Pocahontas_ is the first public publication of the Powhatan perspective that has been maintained and passed down from generation to generation within the Mattaponi Tribe, and the first written history of Pocahontas by her own people.  A fuller understanding of the context of history will be gained.
resources.note: This book contains sensitive content. Lesson Plans will alert students and teachers to specific readings to allow for prereading, guidance, and discussion.

resources.title: The Two Princes of Calabar: An Eighteenth Century Atlantic Odyssey
resources.author: Randy J. Sparks
resources.rationale: This book serves to widen students' understanding of the Atlantic slave trade using source documentation from an African perspective.

resources.title: The Ultimate Guide to Modern Calligraphy & Hand Lettering for Beginners
resources.author: June & Lucy
resources.rationale: Ways to use lettering with brush or pen.

resources.title: The Ultimate Homeschool Physical Education Game Book
resources.author: Guy Bailey
resources.maySub: The Physical Educator's Big Book of Sport Lead-Up Games if you have a co-op or school.
resources.rationale: This book contains time-honored and newer playground games and skill-building activities for organized sports.

resources.title: The Unbreakable Code
resources.author: Sara Hunter
resources.rationale: RATIONALE: A grandfather tells the story of his experience as a Navajo Code Talker during World World II. A fascinating look at how the Navajo language was used to help the Allies beat the Japanese.
resources.note: Used briefly. You may wish to check out from the library.

resources.title: The Underground Railroad: Next Stop, Toronto!
resources.author: Adrienne Shad, Afua Cooper, & Karolyn Smardz Frost

resources.title: The Universe in You: A Microscopic Journey
resources.author: Jason Chin
resources.rationale: This stunning picture book introduces students to Things-too-small-to-see.  With beautiful artwork and accessible language, this title is sure to inspire everyone to look more closely.

resources.title: The Very First Americans
resources.author: Cara Ashrose & Bryna Waldman
resources.rationale: This book gives a brief overview of how humans came to North America and how the very diverse people groups lived.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: The Virtual Instructor (Art)
resources.rationale: This is a wonderful art teacher resource for students.

resources.title: The Wall: Growing Up Behind the Iron Curtain
resources.author: Peter Sis

resources.title: The Wanderings of Odysseus: The Story of the Odyssey
resources.author: Rosemary Sutcliff
resources.rationale: Homer's sequel to The Iliad, retold by Rosemary Sutcliff.

resources.title: The Way Things Work: Newly Revised Edition: The Ultimate Guide to How Things Work
resources.author: David Macaulay
resources.maySub: other editions
resources.rationale: This well-written and humorously illustrated classic guides readers through the fundamental principles of machines and shows how the developments of the past are building blocks of the world of tomorrow.

resources.title: The Way We Work
resources.author: David Macaulay
resources.rationale: A well-illustrated introduction to anatomy.

resources.title: The White House: An Illustrated Architectural History
resources.author: Patrick Phillips-Schrock

resources.title: The Whydah: A Pirate Ship Feared, Wrecked, and Found
resources.author: Martin Sandler

resources.title: The Wiersbe Bible Commentary OT: The Complete Old Testament in One Volume
resources.author: Warren Wiersbe
resources.maySub: May sub a different commentary from your faith tradition.
resources.rationale: Well-developed, approachable Bible study resource by respected Bible teacher, Warren Wiersbe. Includes book introductions and outlines, maps and charts, and verse-by-verse explanations and insight.

resources.title: The Winter of Red Snow
resources.author: Kristiana Gregory
resources.rationale: Eleven-year-old Abigail Jane Stewart's fictionalized diary about her life, family, friends, and neighbors--and the sides they have to choose in Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, during the height of the Revolutionary War--renders a vivid portrayal of one of the most memorable and crucial winters in American history

resources.title: The Winter People
resources.author: Joseph Bruchac
resources.rationale: This novel is set during the French and Indian War. It is based on real historical events, specifically the 1759 attack on St. Francis (Odanak), an Abenaki village in present-day Canada, by Robert Rogers and his rangers. The story follows Saxso, a 14-year-old Abenaki boy, who must embark on a perilous journey from his village to the New England area to rescue his mother and sisters after they are taken captive. Joseph Bruchac, who is of Abenaki descent, does a good job weaving elements of Native American culture, history, and values into the narrative. He also shows the influence of the Jesuits on the Natives, how Christianity influenced their lives, and their relationships with the French people.

resources.title: The Winter's Tale (Audio recording)
resources.author: Arkangel
resources.maySub: Librivox recording

resources.title: The Witch of Blackbird Pond
resources.author: Elizabeth George Speare
resources.rationale: In this Newbery Medal–winning novel, a girl faces prejudice and accusations of witchcraft in seventeenth-century Connecticut. A classic of historical fiction that continues to resonate across the generations.

resources.title: The Witness of Early Christian Women: Mothers of the Church
resources.author: Mike Aquilina
resources.rationale: Source documents/writings alongside short biographies of women and their impact in the early church.

resources.title: The Wolves and Moose of Isle Royale: Restoring an Island Ecosystem
resources.author: Nancy F. Castaldo
resources.rationale: Students discover the threatened predator-prey relationship that maintains the Isle Royale ecosystem in this fascinating story. Will scientists be able to restore the balance?  Let's follow this living laboratory experiment.

resources.title: The Woodworkers
resources.author: Bobbie Kalman & Deanna Brady
resources.rationale: See how the village cooper made barrels and other important things out of wood during Colonial times, and find out about apprenticeship.

resources.title: The Word Made Fresh
resources.author: Abram Van Engen
resources.rationale: A new book which just came out this year, Van Engen lays out a beautiful relational approach to poetry which resonates deeply with Mason (one chapter is titled "Think of Poetry Like Friendship"). As he models a love for poetry and gives insights into how to enjoy, understand, and read poetry (or start on the journey!), students will continue growing their own delight.
resources.note: The first section of the book (the more practical part) is scheduled in the lesson plans, but we recommend the whole book - which concludes with a theological reflection on the value of poetry - as a resource for parents and teachers.

resources.title: The World David Knew: Connecting the Vast Ancient World to Israel's Great King
resources.author: Museum of the Bible Books, Randy Southern
resources.rationale: Shepherd. Warrior. King. Psalmist. Father. Fugitive. Hero. Villain. No single word is sufficient to encompass Israel's King David. The World David Knew offers a snapshot of life in 1000 BC.

resources.title: The World in a Grain: The Story of Sand and How It Transformed Civilization
resources.author: Vince Beiser
resources.rationale: A surprising look at the role sand plays in our modern world.  Who knew that there are people who try to steal beaches?

resources.title: They Dance in the Sky: Native American Star Myths
resources.author: Jean Guard Monroe & Ray A. Williamson
resources.rationale: This book tells the Native American stories behind constellations. It would be particularly good for those with high interest and some background in astronomy.

resources.title: They Fought Like Demons: Women Soldiers in the Civil War
resources.author: Deanne Blanton & Lauren M. Cook

resources.title: Think: The Life of the Mind and the Love of God
resources.author: John Piper
resources.rationale: A focus on using both heart and mind to know and love God and care for others.
resources.note: Choose this OR Atomic Habits

resources.title: Thirteen Moons on Turtle's Back: A Native American Year of Moons
resources.author: Joseph Bruchac & Jonathan London
resources.rationale: In Native American legend, the thirteen scales on a turtle's back symbolize the annual thirteen cycles of the moon and the seasonal changes each one brings. The thirteen poems in this book -- one for each moon of the year, and each from a different indigenous group -- celebrate the natural world and weave together traditional knowledge and folklore. Each poem is illustrated by a beautiful painting.

resources.title: This Day: Collected and New Sabbath Poems
resources.author: Wendell Berry

resources.title: This is Greece
resources.author: Miroslav Sasek
resources.rationale: Capture the flavor and tradition of the birthplace of Western civilization!

resources.title: This is How We Do It
resources.author: Matt Lamothe

resources.title: This is Our Constitution
resources.author: Khizr Khan
resources.rationale: This book about the Constitution is written by a Gold Star father who was born in Pakistan and later became an American citizen. His love for freedom and his appreciation for the fundamental rights found in America shines through as he helps readers understand the Constitution and Bill of Rights.

resources.title: This Strange Wilderness: The Life and Art of John James Audubon
resources.author: Nancy Plain

resources.title: Thomas Day: African American Furniture Maker
resources.author: Rodney Barfield
resources.rationale: Furniture and architecture from the time period

resources.title: Thomas Day: Master Craftsman and Free Man of Color
resources.author: Patricia Marshall
resources.rationale: Furniture and architecture from the time period

resources.title: Thomas Jefferson's Creme Brulee
resources.author: Thomas J. Craughwell
resources.rationale: A look at the cultural crossover between nations.

resources.title: Thomas Jefferson's Monticello
resources.author: Monticello Staff, Lucia "Cinder" Stanton, et al.

resources.title: Thoughts and Sentiments on the Evils of Slavery
resources.author: Quobna Ottobah Cugoano

resources.title: Thoughts to Make Your Heart Sing
resources.author: Sally Lloyd-Jones
resources.rationale: Whimsical art alongside brief readings from various scripture passages and Christian authors to inspire new thoughts of God in young children (and adults).

resources.title: Three Stones Make a Wall
resources.author: Eric Cline, Glynnis Fawkes
resources.rationale: In 1922, Howard Carter peered into Tutankhamun’s tomb for the first time, the only light coming from the candle in his outstretched hand. Urged to tell what he was seeing through the small opening he had cut in the door to the tomb, the Egyptologist famously replied, “I see wonderful things.” Carter’s fabulous discovery is just one of the many spellbinding stories told in _Three Stones Make a Wall_. Written by Eric Cline, an archaeologist with more than thirty seasons of excavation experience, this book traces the history of archaeology from an amateur pursuit to the cutting-edge science it is today by taking the reader on a tour of major archaeological sites and discoveries. Along the way, it addresses the questions archaeologists are asked most often: How do you know where to dig? How are excavations actually done? How do you know how old something is? Who gets to keep what is found? Taking readers from the pioneering digs of the eighteenth century to today’s exciting new discoveries, _Three Stones Make a Wall_ is a lively and essential introduction to the story of archaeology.

resources.title: Thrown to the Wind
resources.author: Amanda M. Cetas
resources.rationale: This novel, which is based on a true story, takes students back to France in the late 1700s to learn about a family who flees France to avoid arrest for religious heresy. The author recreates the sights, sounds, and emotions of an era, which helps students to feel as if they are experiencing events alongside historical figures. Students will learn about France, Amsterdam, and New Netherland as they journey along with nine-year-old Etienne as he faces robbers, pirates, two perilous sea voyages, and an uncertain future to chart a new destiny.

resources.title: Thunder Rolling in the Mountains
resources.author: Scott O'Dell
resources.rationale: As Americans settled farther and further west, conflicts with the indigenous people escalated to a point of crisis. This is the true story of the Nez Perce and Chief Joseph, who were ordered to leave their land and move to a reservation.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Thunderstorm in Church
resources.author: Louise A. Vernon
resources.rationale: This historical fiction book is about Martin Luther, the 16th-century Protestant Reformer. Through the eyes of Luther's son, students will come to know Martin Luther not only as the great Reformer-preacher, but also as a father with a sense of humor and as a friend.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read over the year.

resources.title: Tiny Bird: A Hummingbird's Amazing Journey
resources.author: Robert Burleigh

resources.title: To Be a Christian: An Anglican Catechism
resources.author: J.I. Packer
resources.rationale:
May sub one of the other catechisms.
A basic summary of scriptural truths used in the church for centuries.

resources.title: To Fly: The Story of the Wright Brothers
resources.author: Wendie Old
resources.maySub: First to Fly by Peter Busby
resources.rationale: This book tells the story of an important technology that students have probably observed and maybe even used. Along the way, they learn how the Wright Brothers were driven by curiosity and inspiration and how they persisted to solve one of the biggest challenges of their day.

resources.title: To the Edges of the Earth: 1909, the Race for the Three Poles, and the Climax of the Age of Exploration
resources.author: Edward J. Larson

resources.title: To the Future, Ben Franklin! (Magic Tree House)
resources.author: Mary Pope Osborne
resources.rationale: Travel back in time with two siblings as they visit Old Philadelphia in 1787 to help Dr. Ben!

resources.title: Tomboy Bride
resources.author: Harriet Fish Backus
resources.rationale: Subtitled: A Woman's Personal Account of Life in Mining Camps of the West.

resources.title: Tracking Trash
resources.author: Loree Griffin Burns
resources.rationale: Students follow a scientist who uses creative methods to better understand ocean currents and our impact on life within the sea.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Tracks, Scats, and Signs
resources.author: Leslie Dendy
resources.rationale: Activity book: take along guide

resources.title: Traitor in the Tower: Introducing John Bunyan
resources.author: Dave & Neta Jackson
resources.rationale: This book follows the fictional character of twelve-year-old Richard Winslow, who stays behind in London instead of escaping with the rest of his family to Scotland to help his imprisoned father, only to form a life-changing bond with the historical figure of John Bunyan, a preacher facing execution for his beliefs. Richard must decide whether or not to betray Bunyan to save his father, learning powerful lessons about courage, sacrifice, and faith along the way. Since second and third-graders read Pilgrim's Progress, they might be especially interested to hear about the life of the famous author.

resources.title: Transformed by Truth
resources.author: Katherine Forster
resources.rationale: This book is written for students to encourage them to make Bible reading a special time of their day. The author demonstrates the practices of observation, interpretation, and application so students can discover how God's truth can literally transform them from the inside out. These practices will also be implemented during the NT Bible lessons.

resources.title: Travels of William Bartram edited
resources.author: Mark van Doren
resources.rationale: Source documentation allowing us to "see" the Southeast during our time period.
resources.note: Beware of many other reprints of this book currently available on Amazon that have very small print.

resources.title: Treasure Island
resources.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
resources.rationale: A swashbuckling pirate adventure story loosely set in the 1700s, Treasure Island tells of young Jim Hawkins, who, through disconcerting circumstances, finds himself in possession of a treasure map. When he shows it to a local squire, they decide to set out to follow it. However, unbeknownst to them, they have made the mistake of hiring the infamous pirate Long John Silver as part of their crew!
resources.note: Grades 7-8 should choose this OR the Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee

resources.title: Tree Finder - Eastern US
resources.author: May Watts
resources.rationale: Regional guide
resources.note: Choose a Tree Finder or comparable guide for your area.

resources.title: Tree of Freedom
resources.author: Rebecca Caudill
resources.rationale: When the Venable family moves from Carolina to Kentucky in 1780, they meet with rival claims to their new land as well as harsh demands for their sons to be Revolutionary War recruits.

resources.title: Tuk and the Whale
resources.author: Raquel Rivera
resources.rationale: _Tuk and the Whale_ is a work of historical fiction, which imagines a seventeenth-century encounter between the Inuit of Baffin Island and a beleaguered European whaling ship that strayed from its expected route. Wary of each other, unable to communicate, yet united in a common purpose - the whale hunt - these two groups interacted for the first time to form a tentative partnership and begin to learn from each other. Since the story is told from the perspective of Tuk, a young Inuit boy, it is engaging for young readers, and it presents a vivid depiction of a way of life that has now largely vanished.
resources.note: This is good as an independent read for Grade 4 or confident readers.

resources.title: Turning Points in American Church History
resources.author: Elesha J. Coffman
resources.rationale: An insightful look at some key moments leading up to, during, and following our current history rotation to give more context and perspective on how these events have impacted the American church.
resources.note: This book will be used in other history rotations.

resources.title: Turtle Island
resources.author: Yellowhorn & Lowinger
resources.rationale: Based on archeological finds and scientific research, we now have a clearer picture of how the Indigenous people lived in the Americas. Using that knowledge, the authors take the reader back thousands of years ago to imagine moments in time. The importance of story-telling among the Native peoples is always present to shed light on how they explained their world. The end of the book takes us to modern times when the story of the Native peoples is both tragic and hopeful.

resources.title: TV Shapes Presidential Politics in the Kennedy-Nixon Debates
resources.author: Michael Burgan
resources.rationale: Photographic depiction of the first debates ever held between two presidential candidates and the first to be televised. Readers will learn just how much effect seeing the debates had on the results of the election and how they changed presidential campaigning forevermore.

resources.title: Typing.com
resources.rationale: This program uses fun activities and games to teach keyboarding fluency.
resources.note: Create a free account.

resources.title: Unearthing the Bible: 101 Archaeological Discoveries That Bring the Bible to Life
resources.author: Titus Kennedy
resources.rationale: This book spotlights artifacts from biblical history and explains their stories and significance.

resources.title: United States Atlas 6th Ed.
resources.author: National Geographic  Kids
resources.maySub: 5th edition. Other atlases may be used; however, map work and other lessons refer specifically to this one.
resources.rationale: Used across the curriculum as a reference and as a text to read in some lessons. With interesting information and pictures, this is an economical reference for students.
resources.note: Optional for Grade 1. For US students as well as Canadian students in Grades 2-3.

resources.title: United States Atlas 7th Ed.
resources.author: National Geographic Kids
resources.maySub: earlier edition. Other atlases may be used; however, map work and other lessons refer specifically to this one.
resources.rationale: This atlas is used across the curriculum as a reference and as a text to read in some lessons. With interesting information and pictures, this is an economical reference for students.
resources.note: Optional for Grade 1. For U.S. students.

resources.title: United Tastes of America: An Atlas of Food Facts & Recipes from Every State!
resources.author: Gabrielle Langholtz

resources.title: Unseen Worlds: Real-Life Microscopic Creatures Hiding All Around Us
resources.author: Hélène Rajcak and Damien Laverdunt

resources.title: Untangling Emotions
resources.author: J. Alasdair Groves & Winston T. Smith
resources.rationale:
Our emotions are complex. Some of us seem able to ignore our feelings, while others feel controlled by them. But most of us would admit that we don’t always know what to do with how we feel.
The Bible teaches us that our emotions are an indispensable part of what makes us human―and play a crucial role in our relationships with God and others. Exploring how God designed emotions for our good, this book shows us how to properly engage with our emotions―even the more difficult ones like fear, anger, shame, guilt, and sorrow―so we can better understand what they reveal about our hearts and handle them wisely in everyday moments.

resources.title: Up from Slavery
resources.author: Booker T. Washington
resources.rationale: This is a first-person account of what it was like to be born on a slave plantation, live through the Civil War and Reconstruction, and make a new life as a free person. Washington's accomplishments and sense of hope are inspiring, and his founding of the Tuskegee Institute which continues as a historically black university and National Historic Site today is a remarkable achievement, even taking into consideration the later unethical research problems that have come to light in more recent years.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: Up in the Garden and Down in the Dirt
resources.author: Kate Messner
resources.maySub: any life-giving picture book about garden habitats as preferred by the teacher.
resources.rationale: This beautiful picture book takes us on a trip to the garden alongside a girl and her grandmother. It is a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.
resources.note: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: US Wall Map (US students only)
resources.author: National Geographic
resources.maySub: any US wall map that shows both geographical features and place names. Avoid maps with roadways, as these obscure other features.
resources.rationale: This map clearly shows landforms, and its projection is more accurate than some other maps.
resources.note: Hang map at student eye level.

resources.title: Value of Folktales
resources.author: Rebecca Sheir
resources.rationale: This podcast episode is a wonderful teacher resource on the value of folktales. Rebecca Sheir shares how folktales entertain, inspire, and unite us in this noisy, high-tech world, and act as a bridge between cultures and communities.

resources.title: Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World
resources.author: Timothy Brook
resources.rationale: Using the objects and people of Vermeer's paintings, the author delves into the cultural impact of the global trade routes.

resources.title: Victory on the Walls: A Story of Nehemiah
resources.author: Frieda Clark Hyman
resources.rationale: This historical novel is told through the eyes of Nehemiah's nephew and illustrates a turning point in Jewish history--when King Artaxerxes allows his cupbearer, Nehemiah, to return to Jerusalem to rebuild the walls.The reader makes fascinating connections between events in the Bible and other historical events that happened simultaneously. Students might assume that Bible history took place in a vacuum, but this book will help them understand how events that took place in nearby countries affected God's people.

resources.title: Vietnam: A History of the War
resources.author: Russell Freedman

resources.title: Voices from Colonial America: New France
Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends
resources.author: Kathryn Bridge
resources.rationale:
_Voices of the Elders _is a compelling collection of oral histories, mythology, traditions, and historical events of the Huu-ay-aht First Nation, whose ancestral home is found at Barkley Sound, on the west coast of Vancouver Island. It is an accessible book that allows students to learn about this Indigenous community through their own words and stories.
For students also taking the Canadian option for Grade 8 Geography, this book is an interesting companion to _Frances Barkley_, since Barkley's voyage with her sea-captain husband was an early contact the Huu-ay-aht people had with Europeans, and that part of Vancouver Island was named for Barkley's discovery.

resources.title: Walks with a Naturalist: Living Nature Reader Volume 1
resources.author: Alveary

resources.title: Walks with a Naturalist: Living Nature Reader Volume 2
resources.author: Alveary

resources.title: Water Dance
resources.author: Thomas Locker
resources.rationale: This beautifully illustrated book is a great way to talk about the journey that water takes across our world.
resources.note: Teachers may wish to check this book out from the library rather than purchase it, as it is only used for a couple of lessons.

resources.title: Water is Water: A Book About the Water Cycle
resources.author: Miranda Paul

resources.title: Watership Down
resources.author: Richard Adams
resources.rationale: A worldwide bestseller for over thirty years, _Watership Down _is one of the most beloved novels of all time. Set in England’s Downs, a once idyllic rural landscape, this stirring tale follows a band of very special creatures on their flight from the intrusion of man and the certain destruction of their home. Led by a stouthearted pair of brothers, they journey from their native Sandleford Warren, through the harrowing trials posed by predators and adversaries, and toward the dream of a mysterious promised land and a more perfect society.

resources.title: Weather Words and What they Mean
resources.author: Gail Gibbons

resources.title: Wee Sing: Dutch Girl Medley
resources.rationale: Sampling of some jump rope songs. Good example of children jumping and seeing how to jump and run in.

resources.title: Westward with Fremont: The Story of Solomon Carvalho
resources.author: Sophie Greenspan
resources.note: Use option one link to receive discount.

resources.title: Wet Cement: A Mix of Concrete Poems
resources.author: Bob Raczka

resources.title: What a Plant Knows
resources.author: Daniel Chamovitz
resources.rationale: A plant knows more than you think!  This piece of botany literature provides a fascinating look at plants.
resources.note: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting.

resources.title: What Adults Don't Know About Architecture
resources.author: The School of Life
resources.rationale: This book is a great introduction to architecture and helps students think about the principles behind design and how architecture affects people and communities.

resources.title: What Are You Figuring Now?: A Story about Benjamin Banneker
resources.author: Jeri Ferris
resources.rationale: This is the wonderful story of Benjamin Banneker, a free black man born in Maryland in the 1700s. He was known for his accomplishments in science, as well as surveying Washington, D.C., and creating an almanac.

resources.title: What Is Poetry?
resources.author: Michael Rosen
resources.rationale: This book is full of interesting ideas about poetry. The style is wonderfully readable and engaging and takes away the intimidation factor when it comes to both reading and writing poetry.
resources.note: We will read the whole book this year.

resources.title: What Linnaeus Saw
resources.author: Karen Beil
resources.rationale: Follow the life of an eminent Swedish botanist as he works and travels in the northern latitudes.

resources.title: What Makes Day and Night
resources.author: Franklyn M. Branley
resources.rationale: Through diagrams, pictures, and simple text, this book helps students gain a better understanding of how the rotation of the earth gives us day and night.
resources.note: Teachers may wish to check this book out from the library rather than purchase it, as it is only used for a couple of lessons. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

resources.title: What Would Keynes Do?
resources.author: Tejvan Pettinger
resources.rationale: An easy-to-follow introduction to economics and how it applies to real-life decisions from a variety of economic theory approaches.
resources.note: Used in grades 10 & 11.

resources.title: What's Smaller Than a Pygmy Shrew?
resources.author: Robert E. Wells

resources.title: When a Line Bends, a Shape Begins
resources.author: Rhonda Growler Greene

resources.title: When Apples Grew Noses and White Horses Flew: Tales of Ti-Jean
resources.author: Jan Andrews
resources.rationale: Stories of Quebec's traditional folktale hero, Ti-Jean.

resources.title: When Asia Was the World
resources.author: Stewart Gordon
resources.rationale: Linked together by a web of spiritual, commercial, and intellectual connections, the distant regions of Asia's vast civilization, from Arabia to China, hummed with trade, international diplomacy, and the exchange of ideas. Stewart Gordon has fashioned a compelling and unique look at Asia from AD 700 to 1500-a time when Asia was the world-by relating the personal journeys of Asia's many travelers.

resources.title: When Lightning Struck!: The Story of Martin Luther
resources.author: Danika Cooley
resources.rationale: This historical novel on Martin Luther’s life shows how his questions and desire to learn more about faith led him to read the Bible while a law student. What he learned by reading the Bible, specifically the book of Romans, would change the world.
resources.note: Choose ONE biography (or more) from this list to read.

resources.title: When the Church Was Young: Voices of the Early Fathers
resources.author: Marcellino D'Ambrosio
resources.rationale: Biographies from early church history.
resources.note: ONLY Grades 10-12.

resources.title: Where Do You Think You're Going, Christopher Columbus?
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: This engaging biography introduces students to the life of Christopher Columbus. The author tells about Columbus's passion for sailing, the ideas that captivated him, and the voyage that brought him to the Americas instead of the Indies. This book also talks about Columbus's life after his initial voyage and how he paved the way for future exploration even though he never realized he had landed in a New World unknown to the Europeans.

resources.title: Where Poppies Grow: A World War I Companion
resources.author: Linda Granfield

resources.title: Where Was Patrick Henry on the 29th of May?
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: A short, entertaining biography of Patrick Henry.

resources.title: Why Buildings Stand Up
resources.author: Mario Salvadori
resources.rationale: Used to give a solid and interesting introduction to building principles.

resources.title: Why Don't You Get a Horse, Sam Adams?
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: A short, entertaining biography of Sam Adams.

resources.title: Why Not, Lafayette?
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: Explore the life of a French soldier who fought side-by-side with General Washington.

resources.title: Wigwam Stories Told by North American Indians
resources.author: Mary Catherine Judd
resources.rationale: This is a collection of traditional stories from various indigenous tribes. This book is in the Public Domain and can be accessed on Hathitrust.org.

resources.title: Wildlife Wonders: Canadian Animals Colouring Book
resources.author: Geoff G. N.

resources.title: Will Kemp Art School
resources.author: Will Kemp
resources.rationale: This is a wonderful acrylic and oil art teacher resource for students.

resources.title: Will You Sign Here, John Hancock?
resources.author: Jean Fritz
resources.rationale: A short, entertaining biography of John Hancock.

resources.title: William Bradford: Plymouth's Faithful Pilgrim
resources.author: Gary D. Schmidt
resources.rationale: This is a wonderful biography of William Bradford, the governor of Plymouth Colony for 30 years. This book will help students have a deeper understanding of the Pilgrims and what life was like for them in Europe, both in England and Holland, that caused them to leave and start a new colony in America.  Their daily lives, their struggles, their relationship with the Native Americans, and their strong faith in God are clearly communicated in this book.
resources.note: For Grades 9-10 World History, choose ONE of the biographies listed for Term 3.

resources.title: William Wilberforce
resources.author: Geoff and Janet Benge
resources.rationale: Narrative biography of William Wilberforce, English member of Parliament, social reformer, and abolitionist who worked for decades to abolish slavery in the British Empire.

resources.title: Winter Sleep: A Hibernation Story
resources.author: Sean Taylor
resources.maySub: any life-giving picture book about a winter habitat preferred by the teacher.
resources.rationale: This beautiful picture book takes readers on a winter walk with a boy and his grandmother. It is a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.

resources.title: Winter Tree Finder (Eastern US)
resources.author: May Watts & Tom Watts
resources.rationale: Regional guide
resources.note: Choose a Tree Finder or comparable guide for your area.

resources.title: Winters in the World: A Journey through the Anglo Saxon Year
resources.author: Eleanor Parker
resources.rationale: _Winters in the World _is a beautifully observed journey through the cycle of the year in Anglo-Saxon England, exploring the festivals, customs, and traditions through surviving poetry, literature, and historical documents.

resources.title: Wisdom for Faithful Reading
resources.author: John H. Walton
resources.rationale: In _Wisdom for Faithful Reading_, the trusted Old Testament scholar John Walton lays out his tried-and-true best practices developed over four decades in the classroom. His principles are memorable, practical, and enlightening.

resources.title: Wit and Wisdom from Poor Richard's Almanack
resources.author: Benjamin Franklin
resources.rationale: This is a practical and entertaining collection of aphorisms on life from a significant American thinker.

resources.title: With pipe, paddle, and song: A story of the French-Canadian voyageurs
resources.author: Elizabeth Yates (author)
resources.rationale: This book has some outdated descriptions of Indigenous Canadians

resources.title: Wix Tomorrow Classroom
resources.rationale: Good option to introduce students to Web design.

resources.title: Wolf Mother
resources.author: Hetxw'ms Gyetxw (Brett D. Huson)
resources.rationale: Also available on Kindle and at many libraries.

resources.title: Women Heroes of the American Revolution
resources.author: Susan Casey
resources.rationale: This book highlights the often-overlooked contributions of women during the American Revolution. Through engaging narrative as well as excerpts of personal letters and newspaper articles, the author tells the stories of 20 women including Phillis Wheatley, Sybil Ludington, and Deborah Sampson. Readers get a fuller understanding of what life was like in America during these tumultuous years.

resources.title: WonderFull: Ancient Psalms Ever New
resources.author: Marty Machowski
resources.rationale: In this book, the author weaves together a story and age-appropriate commentary to guide students through the readings of the Psalms. Students will learn how to pray the Psalms and understand the different types of Psalms. This book is read as part of the lesson.

resources.title: Wood Shop: Handy Skills and Creative Building Projects for Kids
resources.author: Margaret Larson
resources.rationale: With step-by-step photographs and clear instructions, aspiring woodworkers learn essential skills, such as how to drive a nail; use a power drill; “measure twice, cut once;” and saw correctly.

resources.title: Woods Runner
resources.author: Gary Paulsen
resources.rationale: Samuel, 13, spends his days in the forest, hunting for food for his family. He has grown up on the frontier, far from any news of the war against the King that American patriots have begun near Boston. But the war comes to them when British soldiers take Samuel’s parents away as prisoners. Samuel follows, hiding, moving silently, determined to find a way to rescue them.

resources.title: Woodshop 101 For Kids
resources.author: Craig Stevens
resources.rationale: Twenty-one woodworking lessons that teach the basics of woodworking.

resources.title: Wordsworth: Poems (Everyman's Library)
resources.author: William Wordsworth
resources.rationale: Wordsworth was a Lakeland poet who began writing towards the end of the 18th century. He is best-known for his poems about nature and everyday life.

resources.title: World Jump Ropers Performance
resources.rationale: Inspiration for variations! Competitive Jump Roping.

resources.title: World Wall Map
resources.author: National Geographic
resources.maySub: any world wall map that shows both geographical features and place names
resources.rationale: The projection of this wall map distorts the image less than others. It also makes geographical features easy to find and place names easy to read.
resources.note: Hang map at student eye level.

resources.title: World War II History for Teens: Understanding the Major Battles, Military Strategy, and Arc of War
resources.author: Benjamin Mack-Jackson

resources.title: Writing Magic
resources.author: Gail Carson Levine
resources.rationale: Fun book for young writers about storytelling and the writing process. Elaborates and fleshes out many activities in Grades 9-10.

resources.title: Written in Bone: Buried Lives of Jamestown and Colonial Maryland
resources.author: Sally M. Walker
resources.rationale: An archeological look at life in the colonial era

resources.title: Years of Dust: The Story of the Dust Bowl
resources.author: Albert Marrin

resources.title: You Come Too: Favorite Poems for Readers of All Ages
resources.author: Robert Frost

resources.title: Your Food is Fooling You: How Your Brain is Hijacked by Sugar, Fat, and Salt (Young Readers Edition)
resources.author: David A. Kessler M.D.

resources.title: Your Rugged Constitution
resources.author: Bruce and Esther Findlay
resources.rationale: This book guides students through the text of the Constitution with descriptions that are put in clear, easy-to-understand language, accompanied by commentary and lively drawings so all the ideas and concepts can be easily grasped.

resources.title: Zone Cleaning for Kids
resources.author: Jennie von Eggers
resources.rationale: Handy little step-by-step checklist children can use to make sure they are completing household tasks well and efficiently.
